'''Abdulrab Muhammad Muhammad Ali al-Sayfi''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: ) a Yemeni, became wanted in 2002, by the [[United States Department of Justice]]'s [[FBI]], which was then seeking information about his identity and whereabouts. He was identified as a known associate of the Yemen cell leader, [[Fawaz Yahya al-Rabeei]].
He is no longer listed by the FBI on their "Seeking Information" lists.
== February 12, 2002 Yemeni terror alert == On February 11, 2002, al-Sayfi was named in a suspected Yemen plot, for which he was among 17 suspected terrorists (3 days later reduced to 11 suspects) were added to the FBI's third major "wanted" list, the "[[FBI Seeking Information - Terrorism list#Yemen plot|Seeking Information" list]].<ref>{{cite web|title=FBI - Seeking Information - 2-11-02|url=http://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/2-11-02.htm|publisher=FBI|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020605061032/http://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/2-11-02.htm|archive-date=5 June 2002}}</ref>
By 2006, his details had been removed and archived from the FBI's current main wanted pages.<ref>{{cite web|title=Most Wanted Terrorists|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/wanted_terrorists|publisher=FBI|accessdate=28 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Seeking Information - Terrorism|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/terrorinfo|publisher=FBI|accessdate=28 September 2016}}</ref>
Whether foiled, aborted, or merely incorrect specific intelligence, the February 12, 2002 attack never occurred. However, other [[Terrorism in Yemen|attacks and plots in Yemen]] soon followed.

{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} '''Age fraud''' is [[age fabrication]] or the use of false documentation to gain an advantage over opponents. In football, it is common amongst players belonging to nations where records are not easily verifiable. The media often refer to the player with false documentation as an "age-cheat".
There are several reasons why players choose to use false documentation. In countries that could be considered poor, European [[scout (sport)|scouts]] are looking for young talented players to sign for a European club. The players know that there is a lesser chance of being signed if they are, for example, 23 years old as opposed to 17 years old as there would be less time for the club to develop the player.
FIFA say that "over-age players have been wrongly entered into various youth competitions, often benefiting from an unfair advantage due to their greater physical maturity compared to players of the proper age."<ref>{{cite web|title=Caught by the wrists |url=https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/developing/medical/news/newsid=1121679.html |publisher=FIFA.com |accessdate=13 April 2011 |date=22 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091106072312/http://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/developing/medical/news/newsid%3D1121679.html |archivedate=6 November 2009 }}</ref>
In some cases, it is possible for the player not to know their own date of birth and make an approximate guess when it comes to gaining official documents.
==Examples==
===Africa=== One of the best known examples of a player falsifying documentations is Cameroon's international football defender [[Tobie Mimboe]] who held several documents during the course of his career that indicated he became younger as time went by.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hawkey|first=Ian|title=Feet of the chameleon : the story of African football|year=2009|publisher=Portico|location=London|isbn=978-1-906032-71-5}}</ref>
In 1989 Nigeria's youth national teams were banned by [[FIFA]] for fielding over-age players in FIFA-organised youth tournaments. The birth dates of three players at the 1988 Olympics were different than the ones used by those players at previous tournaments.<ref name=foreveryoung>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/feb/21/nigerian-football-age-old-problem | title = Forever young: Nigerian football's age-old problem | last = | first = |date = 21 February 2010 | work = [[The Guardian]] | accessdate = 12 June 2011}}</ref> The resulting ban lasted for two years and Nigeria was also stripped of its right to host the [[1991 FIFA World Youth Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|title=After The Eaglets Have Landed|url=http://www.nigeriavillagesquare.com/articles/chris-ngwodo/after-the-eaglets-have-landed.html|publisher=NigeriaVillageSquare.com|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=26 February 2007}}</ref>
South African journalist Thomas Kwenaite uncovered several "age-cheats" representing South Africa who participated in an Under-15 age group tournament hosted in France. The captain of that side was a 24-year-old third-year University student from Port Elizabeth.<ref name=supersport-kwenaite>{{cite web|last=Kwenaite|first=Thomas|title=Age cheating has come back to haunt us|url=http://www.supersport.com/football/blogs/thomas-kwenaite/Age_cheating_has_come_back_to_haunt_us|publisher=SuperSport.com|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=10 July 2008}}</ref> After revealing the age of the player, the player's father took Kwenaite to the South African press ombudsman for "slander" before withdrawing his complaint after it was found that school records show that the player would have started school aged 2 years old. Kwenaite also claims that he was told that he was "unpatriotic" for reporting the story.
In late 1999, Anthony Kojo Williams was appointed as head of the [[Nigeria Football Federation]]. He lasted less than three months in the job and was dismissed because, in NFF board member Zaria Sani's words "he has failed to carry the other board members along"<ref>{{cite web|title=Nigerian soccer chief replaced|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/africa/cup_of_nations/cup_news/609067.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=18 January 2000}}</ref> In the 2010 BBC World service documentary ''Africa Kicks'', Williams stated that the Nigerian Government were "afraid of change". He went on to say, "I don't see Nigerian football getting out of the quagmire, the problem it is in today is because it [corruption] is getting deeper and deeper and deeper. From time to time we get flashes where we do well in some competition with overage players and we celebrate. That was one of the issues I looked at, we can't keep using overage players. We use over-age players for junior championships, I know that. Why not say it? It's the truth. We always cheat. It's a fact. When you cheat, you deprive the young stars that are supposed to play in these competitions their rights."<ref>{{cite web|title=Africa Kicks: Part two|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/documentaries/2010/01/100114_africa_kicks_two.shtml|publisher=BBC|year=2010}}</ref>
{{Quote box |title = |tstyle = text-align: left; |width = 200px |quote = We use over-age players for junior championships, I know that. Why not say it? It's the truth. We always cheat. |source = Anthony Kojo Williams, NFF Chairman, 1999-2000. |qalign = right }}
In 2003, Kenya's Under-17 national team were dissolved by the Kenyan Government after some players revealed themselves to be over 18 years of age.<ref>{{cite web|title=Age-cheat team disbanded|url=http://cdnedge.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/2766977.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=15 February 2003}}</ref> The same year, Ghana's Deputy Youth and Sports Minister Joe Aggrey said he wished to stop age cheats.<ref>{{cite web|title=We Cheated In The Past - Joe Aggrey|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/soccer/artikel.php?ID=31610|publisher=Ghanaweb|accessdate=24 May 2011|date=January 2003}}</ref>
In 2009, Nigerian journalist Adokiye Amiesimaka accused the [[Nigeria Football Federation]] (NFF) of being complicit with age-cheats because it gave the nation a competitive advantage. He had what he considered to be proof that some players were overage but the NFF were not interested in taking his complaint seriously.<ref>{{cite web|title=Adokiye: I have documentary evidence|url=http://www.supersport.com/football/article.aspx?id=322582|publisher=Supersport|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=8 November 2009}}</ref>
In December 2010, the [[Senegal Football Federation]] withdrew Diawandou Diagne, Hervé Diédhiou and Samba Diallo from their under-17 national team after it was found they were overage following an MRI scan.<ref>{{cite web|title=Three players removed for age fraud |url=http://www.starafrica.com/en/football/news/article/article/afcon-u17-senegal-three-players-remov-136281.html |publisher=StarAfrica.com |accessdate=13 April 2011 |date=29 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321002502/http://www.starafrica.com/en/football/news/article/article/afcon-u17-senegal-three-players-remov-136281.html |archivedate=21 March 2012 }}</ref>
In February 2011, Ivorian football manager and [[SuperSport (South African TV channel)|SuperSport]] television pundit Mamadou Gaye responded to a question asking who he thought would win the 2011 U-17 World Cup with "...any of the four team representing us [Africa] in the world cup U17 can win the trophee (sic), because at that level we like cheating on our age."<ref>{{cite web|title=Q&A with Mamadou gaye|url=http://www.supersport.com/football/football-features/news/110203/QA_with_Mamadou_Gaye|publisher=Supersport|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=3 February 2011}}</ref>
===Asia=== The [[Asian Football Confederation]] ejected DPR Korea, Tajikistan and Iraq from the [[2008 AFC U-16 Championship]] after qualifying, and Cambodia, Macau, Bangladesh, Tajikistan, Bhutan and Kyrgyzstan were ejected from the qualifying after being found to have fielded over-age players, while Yemen were ejected from the tournament for fielding an overage player.
Sixteen players were banned by AFC in 2000 and eight were banned in the [[2010 AFC U-16 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|title=AFC Propose MRI Solution For Age Cheat Issue ?|url=http://football-asia.net/?p=1078|publisher=Football-Asia.net|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=18 October 2010}}</ref>
AFC introduced age detection methods in its age group competitions in 2000.
===Europe=== Dave Bowler, author of ''Winning Isn't Everything: Biography of Sir Alf Ramsey'', claims that Englishman [[Alf Ramsey]] forged documents so that his date of birth changed from 1920 to 1922. Bowler alleges that Ramsey feared that come the end of the Second World War, he would be considered too old to be offered a professional contract.<ref name="vickery">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/6142694.stm|title=Tim Vickery column|date=13 November 2006|work=BBC sport}}</ref>
Matt Brown of Sherington Veterans claimed to be 37. this was found to be false as be had doctored his birth certificate and was in fact 42. <ref name ="sherington">{{cite web|url=http://fulltime-league.thefa.com/DisplayTeam4.do?divisionseason=483254208&id=274542374&seasonTeamID=703135743|title=AFC SHERINGTON|website=fulltime-league.thefa.com}}</ref>
===The Americas=== In the scandal known as the [[Cachirules]], all of Mexico's international teams were banned for two years by [[FIFA]] from international competition in 1988 when the Under-20 national team was proven to consciously field several over aged players.
During the [[Spanish Civil War]], many documents containing birth details of Spanish citizens were destroyed. Many [[South American]]s used the situation to their advantage and claimed that their parents were of Spanish origin in the hope that they could start a new life in [[Spain]] or become professional players in Spain.
Brazilian [[Carlos Alberto de Oliveira Júnior]] won the [[2003 FIFA World Youth Championship]] using fake documents to claim that he was born on 24 January 1983. Because of this, he was banned for 360 days from football.<ref name="vickery"/>
An Ecuadorian footballer, real name Ángel Cheme, played the majority of his professional career as [[Gonzalo Chila]], which was the real name of a player three years his junior whom he had met when they both had trials at a local club, thus enabling him to play in age-restricted matches for three years after he was entitled to do so; he was eventually suspended for two years.
==Introduction of MRI== The mandatory use of [[Magnetic resonance imaging]] (MRI) was introduced by FIFA in 2009 for the [[2009 FIFA U-17 World Cup|FIFA Under-17 World Cup]] to help ascertain whether players are over age or not.
MRI is considered to be 99% accurate until the age of 17, after which it becomes harder for medical professionals to calculate a person's age. Professor Jiri Dvorak of FIFA said: "The efficiency stops at 17 and it's just pure coincidence that Fifa made their competition an under-17 event".<ref name=bbc-edwards>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Piers|title=An age of change?|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/piersedwards/2011/01/age.html|publisher=BBC Sports|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=21 January 2011}}</ref> Every bone in the arm and leg has an end plate from which bones grow. When the growth is completed (usually around the age of 17-18), then this end plate disappears on the MRI scans.<ref name="bbc-edwards"/> Dvorak concedes that the scan results "will be unjust to 1% of all examined players".<ref name="bbc-edwards"/>
The researchers had classified the scans into 6 grading system, as follows:
{| class="wikitable" width="600px" !Grade !Comment !Eligibility for U16/U17 tournament |- |1 |Completely unfused (physis may be thin) |rowspan="5"|Player eligible |- |2 |Early fusion: minimal hyper intensity within physis |- |3 |Trabecular fusion of less than 50% of radial cross-sectional area (number of sections (full width) with fusion below 50%) |- |4 |Trabecular fusion of more than 50% of radial cross-sectional area (number of sections (full width) above 50%) or more than 5 mm non-fused on any one section |- |5 |Residual physis, less than 5 mm on any one section |- |6 |Completely fused |Player not eligible |}
Source:<ref name="afc-qa">{{cite web|title=Age test Q&A with Dr Gurcharan |url=http://www.the-afc.com/en/football-development/education/20904 |publisher=AFC |accessdate=13 April 2011 |date=20 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130122223032/http://www.the-afc.com/en/football-development/education/20904 |archivedate=22 January 2013 }}</ref>
Of the 429 MRI done by the Asian Football Confederation in 2007, 10 players (or 2.7%) were found to be over the age of 16 years in an otherwise Under-15 tournament. In 2008, one out of the 116 MRI conducted had full fusion.<ref name="afc-qa"/>
Not everybody was pleased by the introduction of MRI, Nigeria had lost 15 players after they were proven to be over-age. Nigeria's Football Federation President Sani Lulu said: "I’ll not use the MRI to disqualify my players."<ref name="gamsports">{{cite web|last=Cham |first=Yusupha |title=Nigeria FA Chief rejects FIFA’s MRI |url=http://www.gamsports.com/nigeria-fa-chief-rejects-fifa-s-mri.html |publisher=Gamsports.com |accessdate=13 April 2011 |date=16 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322164850/http://www.gamsports.com/nigeria-fa-chief-rejects-fifa-s-mri.html |archivedate=22 March 2012 }}</ref> He felt that FIFA had sprung their decision to use MRI upon the nations.
Lulu wanted to invite the parents of the national under-17 players to verify their sons' ages. Nigerian Sports Minister Sani Ndanusa dismissed the parent verification system and stated the "whole world has gone digital and we're following suit. We're no longer in the analogue era."<ref name="okeleji">{{cite web|last=Okeleji|first=Oluwashina|title=Nigeria rejects Fifa age scans|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8259652.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=16 September 2009}}</ref>
Lulu stated that NFF did not need to scan players as it wasn't in the competition's rules and regulations. Ndanusa stated: "FIFA wants MRI scans used and we're going to adhere to that, simple."<ref name="okeleji"/>
For the same tournament, the [[Gambia Football Association]] had scanned 53 of its players and "few" failed. It was suggested that "two or three" whom the MRI scan had revealed to be overage were participants at the [[2009 African Under-17 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Horrocks|first=Jenny|title=Gambia admits to failed age tests|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8271272.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=23 September 2009}}</ref>
In 2011, the [[Confederation of African Football]] (CAF) enforced the use of MRI for the [[2011 African Under-17 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|title=CAF ready to showcase success of MRI to rest of world|url=http://www.cafonline.com/competition/can-u-17_2011/news/7518-caf-ready-to-showcase-success-of-mri-to-rest-of-world.html|publisher=CAFonline.com|accessdate=13 April 2011|date=14 January 2011}}</ref>
In July 2013, sixteen-year-old United States-born [[Abuchi Obinwa]] failed an MRI test when undergoing assessment to represent the Nigeria U17 team at the [[2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Okeleji|first=Oluwashina|title=Obinwa refuses to rule out Nigeria despite MRI scan failure|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24282432|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 September 2013|date=26 September 2013}}</ref>
In August 2016, it was reported that 26 Nigeria U17 players had failed MRI tests prior to their match against Niger U17's.<ref>{{cite web|title=CAF ready to showcase success of MRI to rest of world|url=http://africanfootball.com/news/635461/EXCLUSIVE-Staggering-26-fail-Eaglets-MRI-test-first-team-wiped-out|publisher=africanfootball.com|accessdate=3 August 2016|date=3 August 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26174252|title=Why the problem of age fraud is 'rampant' in African football|date=13 February 2014|accessdate=13 February 2014|author=Andy Cryer|publisher=BBC Sport}}

Everett Koop, Hisashi Nikaidoh | publications = Books | topics = Christianity | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | owner = | numemployees = | url = }}
'''Ambassador International''', a division of Emerald House Group, is a Christian publishing company founded in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in 1980 by Samuel Lowry.<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 Write2Ignite Presenters|url=http://write2ignite.com/the-presenters/|work=Write2Ignite.com|publisher=Write2Ignite|accessdate=20 May 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130830015842/http://write2ignite.com/the-presenters/|archive-date=2013-08-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ambassador International|url=http://vyrso.com/products/search?Publisher=Ambassador+International|work=Vyrso|publisher=Vyrso|accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref><ref>http://ambassador-international.com/about/team/</ref> In 1995, the United States office opened in Greenville, South Carolina.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jenkins|first=Jerry|title=The Christian Writer's Market Guide|year=2013|publisher=Tyndale House Publishers|isbn=1414376405|page=48|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O4meDzYLYE8C&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=ambassador+international+christian+publishing#v=onepage&q=ambassador%20international%20christian%20publishing&f=false}}</ref> Today, the UK office publishes an average of twenty-five titles per year and the US office publishes an average of sixty titles, including fiction.<ref>{{cite web|title=ACFW Recognized Publishers|url=http://www.acfw.com/index.php/about/recognized_publishers|work=American Christian Fiction Writers|publisher=American Christian Fiction Writers|accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref>
Ambassador International published the last authorized biography of gospel singer [[George Beverly Shea]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Christian Retailing Staff|title=Billy Graham Crusade soloist George Beverly Shea dies at 104 following brief illness|date=30 April 2013|url=http://christianretailing.com/index.php/news/industry-news/25630-billy-graham-crusade-soloist-george-beverly-shea-dies-at-104-following-brief-illness|work=ChristianRetailing.com|accessdate=8 May 2013}}</ref> In 2013, Ambassador published ''Healing Hearts'', with a foreword by former [[C. Everett Koop, M.D.|US Surgeon General C. Everett Koop]]. The book was written by pediatric heart surgeon Hisashi Nikaidoh,<ref>{{cite news|last=Jordan|first=Nicole|title=A Heart that Heals: eight mothers and one doctor find healing after losing a child|date=May 2013|url=http://www.dfwchild.com/Dallas/showarticle.asp?artid=2080|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=Dallas Child Magazine|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130629004052/http://www.dfwchild.com/Dallas/showarticle.asp?artid=2080|archive-date=2013-06-29|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> known for the [[Dextro-Transposition of the great arteries#Nikaidoh|procedure that carries his name]]. Nikaidoh wrote the book about his experience of losing his son Hitoshi in a sudden accident in August 2003.
Other Ambassador International authors include Holly Durst, contestant of the reality show [[The Bachelor (season 12)|The Bachelor: Season 12]] and winner of [[Bachelor Pad]] Season 2. Durst's children's book ''Chocolate Socks'' was published in March 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ricketts|first=Whitney|title=Holly Durst Talks Chocolate Socks, Summer Wedding to Blake Julian — Exclusive!|date=13 March 2012|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/the-bachelorette/articles/holly-durst-talks-chocolate-socks-summer-wedding-to-blake-julian-exclusive|work=Wetpaint.com|accessdate=8 May 2013}}</ref><ref>https://www.amazon.com/Chocolate-Socks-Holly-Durst/dp/1620200007</ref> William (Bill) Renje, author of ''A Chosen Bullet: A Broken Man's Triumph Through Faith and Sports'',<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Chosen-Bullet-Triumph-Through-ebook/dp/B004PGNB74</ref> won a gold medal in [[Wheelchair rugby at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|wheelchair rugby in the 1996 Summer Paralympics]] and the [[Wheelchair rugby at the 2000 Summer Paralympics|2000 Summer Paralympics]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith Haney|first=Audra|title=Paralympic Medalist Saved by a Bullet|url=http://www.cbn.com/700club/features/amazing/ASH15_Bill_Renje.aspx?option=print|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=The 700 Club}}</ref> Husband and wife authors Elizabeth and Kevin Morrisey wrote the book ''God's Lineup: Testimonies of Major League Baseball Players'' ''<ref>{{cite news|last=Wildmon|first=Tim|title=Kevin and Elizabeth Morrisey Talk About Their Book Gods Lineup|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0x_K436ByEM|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=American Family Radio: Today's Issues|date=4 June 2012}}</ref><ref>https://www.amazon.com/Lineup-Testimonies-League-Baseball-Players/dp/1935507664/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1367009585&sr=1-1&keywords=God%27s+lineup</ref>'', which features several players, including [[Landon Powell]], [[Trot Nixon]], [[Stephen Drew]] and [[Matt Diaz]]. Ambassador International published missionary David Sitton's book ''Reckless Abandon: A Gospel pioneer's exploits among the most difficult to reach peoples''<ref>{{cite news|last=Schuller Coleman|first=Sheila| title=David Sitton interview excerpt|url=http://vimeo.com/36515180|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=The Hour of Power|date=12 February 2012}}</ref> in 2011, re-releasing the title with new content in 2013. Preacher and [[John Piper (theologian)|theologian John Piper]] endorsed the book.<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Reckless-Abandon-pioneers-exploits-difficult/dp/1620202085/ref=sr_1_5?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1367009865&sr=1-5&keywords=reckless+abandon</ref> The book is dedicated to David's niece, Makayla Sitton, who, along with three other family members, was killed on Thanksgiving night 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dunn|first=Kelley|title=One year ago, Makayla Sitton, 3 other family members were killed Thanksgiving night|url=http://www.wptv.com/dpp/news/region_n_palm_beach_county/jupiter/One-year-ago,-Makayla-Sitton,-3-other-family-members-were-killed-Thanksgiving-night|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=WPTV|date=24 November 2010}}</ref>

1962–1965, 1967–1969 (Reserve) |battles = [[Vietnam War]] }} '''Robert Clinton Smith''' (born March 30, 1941) is an [[United States|American]] [[politician]] who served as a member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] for [[New Hampshire's 1st congressional district]] from 1985 to 1990 and the state of [[New Hampshire]] in the [[United States Senate]] from 1990 to 2003. First elected to the House of Representatives as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] in 1984, he was re-elected twice before running for the Senate [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 1990|in 1990]], winning the open seat and assuming it early when incumbent [[Gordon J. Humphrey]] resigned. He was re-elected [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 1996|in 1996]] and then entered the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2000|Republican primary]] for the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 presidential election]]. After failing to gain traction, he withdrew before the primaries began and joined the [[Constitution Party (United States)|Taxpayers' Party]], seeking their nomination instead. He then changed parties again, becoming an [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] before dropping out of the presidential race altogether. He then re-joined the Republican Party after the Chairmanship of the [[United States Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works|Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works]] became open, which he then assumed. Smith ran for re-election [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2002|in 2002]] but lost the Republican primary to Congressman [[John E. Sununu]], who won the general election. After his defeat he moved to Florida and briefly ran for the Senate from there [[United States Senate election in Florida, 2004|in 2004]] and [[United States Senate election in Florida, 2010|in 2010]], but dropped out early on in both cases after faring poorly in polls of the Republican primary. He subsequently returned to New Hampshire, where he declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination in the [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2014|2014 Senate election]], but was subsequently defeated in the Republican primary by former U.S. Senator from Massachusetts [[Scott Brown (politician)|Scott Brown]]. ==Early life== Smith was born in [[Trenton, New Jersey]], the son of Margaret (née Eldridge) and Donald Smith.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=010fAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=New Hampshire Notables: Presenting Biographical Sketches of Men and Women who Have Helped Shape the Character of the Granite State|last=Brereton|first=Charles|date=1986|publisher=New Hampshire Historical Society|isbn=9780914339113|language=en}} He obtained a [[bachelor's degree]] from [[Lafayette College]] in 1965 and did graduate work at [[California State University, Long Beach]]. He served in the [[United States Navy Reserve]] from 1962 to 1965, and was on active duty from 1965 to 1967, including a year in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]]. He remained in the Navy Reserve until 1969. Smith settled in [[Wolfeboro, New Hampshire]], where he taught [[history]] and [[English language|English]]. He also served on his local school board and got into the [[real estate]] business as owner and operator of the Yankee Pedlar brokerage. ==Political career== ===U.S. House of Representatives=== [[File:Bob Smith with Ronald Reagan.jpg|thumb|right|Smith with [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]]]] Smith ran for [[New Hampshire's 1st congressional district]] in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1982#New Hampshire|1982 elections]]. With [[Early 1980s recession in the United States|the recession]] and [[Ronald Reagan|President Reagan]]'s unpopularity aiding Democratic candidates, Smith lost to incumbent [[Norman D'Amours]] by 55% to 45%. D'Amours did not seek re-election in [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1984#New Hampshire|1984]], unsuccessfully running for the U.S. Senate instead and Smith was elected in his place, riding Reagan's coattails to beat Democrat [[Dudley Dudley (politician)|Dudley Dudley]] by 59% to 40%. A member of NH's Executive Council, her campaign slogan was "Dudley Dudley, Worth Repeating". Smith responded "Dudley Dudley, Liberal Liberal".{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/cq/2007/01/08/cq_2094.html|title=Dudley Not Redundant for Shea-Porter|date=8 January 2007|accessdate=24 July 2013|work=The New York Times|first=Rachel|last=Kapochunas}} Smith was re-elected [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1986|in 1986]] and [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1988|1988]] by wide margins, first beating Democrat James M. Demers 56% to 44%, then beating Democrat Joseph F. Keefe by 60% to 40%. ===U.S. Senate=== Smith did not run for re-election in 1990, instead running for [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 1990|the U.S. Senate seat]] that was being vacated by retiring Republican [[Gordon J. Humphrey]], who was retiring after pledging not to serve more than two terms. His opponent was Democrat [[John A. Durkin]], who had previously served in the Senate from 1975 to 1980. Smith beat him in a landslide, taking 65% of the vote to Durkin's 31%. Humphrey resigned in December after being elected to the [[New Hampshire Senate]] and Smith was appointed to replace him for the final two months of his term. The [[Vietnam War POW/MIA issue]], concerning the fate of possible missing or captured Americans in Vietnam, became Smith's major issue in Congress in 1985, partly spurred on by his growing up without knowing how his own father died in [[World War II]]. Smith helped create, and served as vice-chairman of, the 1991–1993 [[Senate Select Committee on POW/MIA Affairs]]. Smith ran for re-election [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 1996|in 1996]] and only narrowly defeated Democratic former U.S. Representative [[Richard Swett]], taking 49% of the vote to Swett's 46%. Smith had established himself as the most conservative Senator from the Northeast, and [[Bill Clinton]]'s coattails nearly caused his defeat. On the night of the election many American media networks incorrectly projected that Swett had won.{{cite news |date=December 2, 1996 |authorlink=Susan Crabtree |first=Susan |last=Crabtree |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1571/is_n45_v12/ai_18917399/ |accessdate=2012-04-29 |title=1996 Ad |newspaper=[[Insight on the News]] |quote=An incorrect exit poll by [[Voter News Service]], or VNS, resulted in an early and ultimately incorrect projection of victory in New Hampshire for Democratic Senate candidate Dick Swett over Republican incumbent Sen. Robert C. Smith. "Every election night, you know, its cardiac-arrest time in some state, in some race - sometimes in several races," [[CBS News|CBS]]' [[Dan Rather]] explained at 9:40 p.m. EST. "This race is as hot and tight as a too-small bathing suit on a too-long car ride back from the beach." But the network "oops" came too late for a number of newspapers that featured Swett's exit-poll victory in their early editions.}} During his tenure in the Senate, Smith was a strident opponent of [[gay rights]]. In 1994, Smith and fellow Republican senator [[Jesse Helms]] of [[North Carolina]] introduced an amendment denying federal funding to schools which promoted [[homosexuality]] in their curricula.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-08-04/news/mn-23437_1_gay-rights|title=Gay Activists Downplay Senate School Bill|last=BOXALL|first=BETTINA|date=1994-08-04|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} The amendment passed by a vote of 63-36.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/02/us/senate-backs-cuts-for-schools-that-endorse-homosexuality.html|title=Senate Backs Cuts for Schools That Endorse Homosexuality|last=Seelye|first=Katharine Q.|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} In October 1997, President [[Bill Clinton]] nominated openly gay diplomat [[James Hormel]] to be [[United States Ambassador to Luxembourg]], the first time an openly LGBT person had been nominated for an ambassadorship. Smith, with fellow Republican Senators [[James Inhofe]] and [[Tim Hutchinson]], campaigned vigorously against Hormel's nomination.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m_boGY8AUTIC | title=Gay and lesbian Americans and political participation: a reference handbook | author=Raymond A. Smith |author2=Donald P. Haider-Markel | year=2002 |location=Santa Barbara, Calif. | publisher=ABC-Clio| isbn=1-57607-256-8}} [[File:Wetlands-conservation-act.jpg|thumb|left|Smith, second from right, watches as [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] signs a bill in 2002.]] In January 1999, at [[Kingswood Regional High School]] in [[Wolfeboro, New Hampshire|Wolfeboro]], Smith announced that he was a candidate for the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2000|Republican nomination]] for President of the United States (at the time the front-runner was [[Governor of Texas|Texas Governor]] [[George W. Bush]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/19/us/native-son-says-he-s-running-and-few-are-happy-about-it.html|title=Native Son Says He's Running, And Few Are Happy About It|date=19 February 1999|accessdate=24 July 2013|work=The New York Times|first=Richard L.|last=Berke}} In July, after failing to gain any ground in the presidential race and before any primaries or caucuses had taken place, Smith announced he was leaving the Republican Party and would seek the nomination of the [[Constitution Party (United States)|Taxpayers' Party]]. One month later, Smith left the Taxpayers Party after claiming that ideologues within the party resisted his candidacy due to his [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] and announced as an [[Independent (politician)|Independent]]. He withdrew completely from the race in October and endorsed Bush. [[File:Bobsmith2000.gif|thumb|right|Logo from Smith's 2000 Presidential campaign]] In the meantime, Republican Senator [[John Chafee]] of [[Rhode Island]] had died and thus the chairmanship of the [[United States Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works|Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works]] had re-opened. Smith recanted his repudiation of the Republican party, claiming it had been "a mistake" and claiming that since he had never officially changed his voting registration that he had never left the party. Smith was then elected as Chafee's successor to the chairmanship.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/03/us/prodigal-smith-named-chairman-of-senate-environment-panel.html?ref=johnhchafee|title=Prodigal Smith Named Chairman of Senate Environment Panel|date=3 November 1999|accessdate=24 July 2013|work=The New York Times|first=Lizette|last=Alvarez}} Some New Hampshire voters were uncomfortable with Smith's passionate way of expressing his views on certain issues. In one case, he used a pair of scissors to stab a plastic doll on the Senate floor to illustrate his anti-abortion stance.{{cite news|last1=Belluck|first1=Pam|title=Senator Smith Ousted in Republican Primary in New Hampshire|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/11/us/senator-smith-ousted-in-republican-primary-in-new-hampshire.html|accessdate=9 October 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=11 September 2002}} In 2000, Smith attempted to assist the Miami-based family of [[Elián González]] after Elián was returned to his [[Elian Gonzales#Elián returned to father's custody|father's custody]] by accompanying them to the entrance of [[Andrews Air Force Base]], where Elián was being held; they were turned away.{{Cite news |title=Raid and Reunion: 'What's happening?' |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=2000-05-01}} Smith ran for re-election to a third term [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2002|in 2002]], but was defeated in the Republican primary by Congressman [[John E. Sununu]], winning 45% of the vote to Sununu's 53%."[http://www.fec.gov/pubrec/fe2002/senate.htm Federal Elections 2002 U.S. Senate Results]". ''Federal Election Commission''. 2002. After his defeat, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that many Republicans were "relieved" that he had lost, having never forgiven him for leaving the party in 1999.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/12/us/campaign-season-gop-is-relieved-at-republican-s-loss.html|title=Campaign Season; G.O.P. Is Relieved At Republican's Loss|date=12 September 2002|accessdate=24 July 2013|work=The New York Times|first=Carl|last=Hulse}} He subsequently moved to [[Sarasota, Florida]] to sell real estate. ==Post-Congressional career== [[File:Governor Charlie Crist chatting with former U.S. Senator from New Hampshire Robert C. "Bob" Smith.jpg|thumb|right|Smith chatting with [[Charlie Crist]] in 2010]] In 2003, Smith founded the American Patriot Foundation, to support "the families of soldiers lost in war."{{Cite web|url=http://www.historycommons.org/entity.jsp?entity=robert_c____bob___smith_1|title=Robert C. ("Bob") Smith|website=www.historycommons.org|access-date=2018-10-15}} {{as of|2014}}, its website describes the group as "a non-partisan, non-profit national foundation with the primary function of educating the American public as to the importance and relevance in today's society of the United States Constitution, the Declaration of Independence, ''[[The Federalist Papers]]'', and other founding documents."{{cite web|url=http://www.americanpatriotfoundation.net/projects.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318181916/http://www.americanpatriotfoundation.net/projects.html |archivedate=2012-03-18 |df= }} In 2003, Smith turned the running of the group over to a friend and it became essentially dormant. The group was re-activated in 2010 during the [[court-martial of Terry Lakin]], a [[lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] in the [[United States Army]], who refused to deploy to [[Afghanistan]] because of his [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|concerns over President Obama's alleged constitutional eligibility to be president]]. The APF supported Lakin and released a video where he explained his intent to disobey what he believed to be "illegal orders". Asked whether he supported the group's work for Lakin, Smith said: "...my personal belief is that when an officer has a constitutional question I don't have a problem with that being answered, that's his legal right to have that answered, but I'm not involved in it."{{cite journal|last1=Koppelman |first1=Alex |date=2010-04-05 |title=New soldier joins Birthers' anti-Obama crusade |journal=[[Salon (magazine)|Salon]] |publisher=Salon Media Group |accessdate=2011-01-02 |url=http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2010/04/05/birther_soldier_terrence_lakin |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vRpMK2xA?url=http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2010/04/05/birther_soldier_terrence_lakin |archivedate=2011-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Smith ran for the [[United States Senate election in Florida, 2004|U.S. Senate seat from Florida in 2004]] against [[Mel Martinez]], but dropped out after raising little money{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/politicselections/state/florida/2004-04-15-smith-florida_x.htm |date=April 15, 2004 |work=Associated Press |title=Former New Hampshire senator ends bid for Florida seat }} and receiving less than 1% support in Republican polls. Martinez would go on to win the election. Less than a month before the November 2004 election, Smith wrote an op-ed for the ''[[Concord Monitor]]'' in which he denounced the lack of Republican outrage over [[2002 New Hampshire Senate election phone jamming scandal|phone jamming]] on Election Day 2002, in which Republican operatives had jammed phone banks used by the Democrats to contact Democratic voters and get them to the polls. Smith implied that this action may have made the difference in Shaheen's narrow loss to Sununu.{{cite news|url=http://www.concordmonitor.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20041019/REPOSITORY/410190316/1037/NEWS04 |title=Phone-jamming was an outrage; Republicans should speak out in anger |work=Concord Monitor |author=Bob Smith |date=October 18, 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080417064111/http://www.concordmonitor.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20041019%2FREPOSITORY%2F410190316%2F1037%2FNEWS04 |archivedate=April 17, 2008 |df= }} On December 21, 2007, Smith endorsed Congressman [[Duncan Hunter]] of California for the Republican presidential nomination. In a letter to New Hampshire Republicans ahead of the first-in-nation New Hampshire Primary, Smith cited Hunter as the best candidate to carry the "Reagan Torch" and the most qualified candidate to protect conservative values.{{cite news|title=Former New Hampshire Sen.Bob Smith Endorses Duncan Hunter for President|url=http://newsblaze.com/story/20071221154639tsop.nb/topstory.html|work=News Blaze|date=December 21, 2007|accessdate=December 21, 2007}} In January 2008, Smith began writing editorials on the web page of the [[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution Party]] (formerly called the U.S. Taxpayers' Party), which fueled speculation that Smith intended to seek the party's presidential nomination. The nomination went to [[Chuck Baldwin]], a Baptist pastor. {{wikinews|Wikinews interviews former Republican U.S. Senator Bob Smith on his latest run for office}}In February 2009, with Martinez having announced that he would retire from the Senate in January 2011, Smith was again considering [[United States Senate election in Florida, 2010|running for the seat]],{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/campaign-2008/former-sen.-bob-smith-weighs-a-run--in-florida-2009-01-29.html |title=Former Sen. Bob Smith weighs a run ... in Florida|author=Aaron Blake |date=January 29, 2009 |work=The Hill }}{{cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNk47-5hh-c |title=Senator Bob Smith On Running for the Florida Senate Seat in 2010|date=February 16, 2009 |work=YouTube }} although it was also reported that he was considering a return to New Hampshire to [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2010|run for the Senate seat there]], especially if his old nemesis [[John E. Sununu]] (who was [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2008|defeated]] for re-election in 2008) sought the seat.{{cite news|url=http://www.politics1.com/blog-0209a.htm#0223|title=The Return of Bob Smith|author=Vin Gopal|date=2009-02-23|work=Politics1.com|access-date=2009-02-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221005920/http://www.politics1.com/blog-0209a.htm#0223#0223|archive-date=2009-02-21|dead-url=yes|df=}} On April 9, 2009, Politico reported that Smith would seek the Republican nomination for Florida's 2010 Senate election.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/glennthrush/0409/Snowbird_Smith_running_in_Florida__again.html#comments|title=Snowbird Smith Running in Florida|author=Glenn Thrush|date=2009-04-09|work=Politico.com}} He dropped out of the race in March 2010, after faring poorly in the polls against [[Governor of Florida|Governor]] [[Charlie Crist]] and [[Marco Rubio]].{{cite web|url=http://politicalinsider.blogs.heraldtribune.com/11105/smith-drops-out-of-senate-race-again/?tc=ar |title=Smith drops out of Senate race again |last=Wallace |first=Jeremy |date=March 30, 2009 |work=Political Insider |publisher=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |accessdate=May 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711163820/http://politicalinsider.blogs.heraldtribune.com/11105/smith-drops-out-of-senate-race-again/?tc=ar |archivedate=July 11, 2011 |df= }} In mid-2013 Smith expressed interest in facing Democratic incumbent [[Jeanne Shaheen]] in the [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2014|2014 Senate election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wmur.com/political-scoop/former-us-sen-bob-smith-not-ruling-out-political-comeback-against-shaheen/-/16254890/21129306/-/w2ewru/-/index.html|title=Former U.S. Sen. Bob Smith not ruling out political comeback against Shaheen|date=23 July 2013|accessdate=24 July 2013|work=WMUR|first=James|last=Pindell|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822221457/http://www.wmur.com/political-scoop/former-us-sen-bob-smith-not-ruling-out-political-comeback-against-shaheen/-/16254890/21129306/-/w2ewru/-/index.html|archivedate=22 August 2013|df=}} In October he ruled out a run,{{cite web|url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20131009/NEWS0602/131009277/-1/news0602|title=John DiStaso's Granite Status: Former Sen. Bob Smith will not try to return to Washington|date=October 9, 2013|accessdate=October 10, 2013|work=New Hampshire Union Leader|author=John DiStaso}} but in December announced that he had reconsidered.{{Cite news|url=http://www.wmur.com/political-scoop/fmr-us-sen-bob-smith-changes-mind-will-challenge-shaheen/-/16254890/23231770/-/brr43f/-/index.html|title=Fmr U.S. Sen. Bob Smith changes mind, will challenge Shaheen|last=Pindell|first=James|date=2013-12-02|work=WMUR|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}} He officially declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination in March 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Politics/Bob-Smith-Jeanne-Shaheen-challenge-NH/2014/03/05/id/556311|title=It's Official: Ex-Sen. Smith to Challenge Shaheen in NH|author=Cathy Burke|date=2014-03-05|work=Newsmax.com}} If Smith had won New Hampshire's 2014 U.S. Senate race, he would have tied [[Dan Coats]]' modern mark for the longest gap in U.S. Senate service in the direct election era (12 years).{{cite web |url= http://editions.lib.umn.edu/smartpolitics/2013/12/04/bob-smith-and-the-12-year-itch/ |title= Bob Smith and the 12-Year Itch |work=Smart Politics |first=Eric |last=Ostermeier |date= December 4, 2013}} However, he lost the primary to [[Scott Brown (politician)|Scott Brown]]. ==Cruz campaign== Smith was one of three co-chairs of the Veterans Coalition supporting [[Ted Cruz]] for the Republican nomination in the [[U.S. presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]]. He is joined in "Vets for Ted" by [[Texas State Senate|Texas State Senator]] [[Brian Birdwell]] and [[U.S. Representative]] [[Jim Bridenstine]] of [[Oklahoma]]. Bill Connor is national director of the coalition.{{cite web|url=https://www.tedcruz.org/news/sen-cruz-names-u-s-sen-bob-smith-congressman-jim-bridenstine-and-texas-sen-brian-birdwell-co-chairs-of-vets-for-ted-bill-connor-to-serve-as-national-director/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150928223144/https://www.tedcruz.org/news/sen-cruz-names-u-s-sen-bob-smith-congressman-jim-bridenstine-and-texas-sen-brian-birdwell-co-chairs-of-vets-for-ted-bill-connor-to-serve-as-national-director/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 28, 2015|title=Sen. Cruz Names U.S. Sen. Bob Smith, Congressman Jim Bridenstine, and Texas Sen. Brian Birdwell Co-chairs of Vets for Ted; Bill Connor to Serve as National Director|publisher=tedcruz.org|accessdate=August 26, 2015}} ==Personal== He and his wife Mary Jo have three children. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091230073147/http://friendsofsenatorbobsmith.com/ Bob Smith for Senate 2010] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050907080456/http://www.seacoastonline.com/1999news/7_13b.htm ''Portsmouth Herald'' — "Smith makes break, leaves GOP"] * {{CongLinks | congbio=S000606 | votesmart= | fec= | congress= }} *{{C-SPAN|bobsmith03}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{s-bef|before=[[Norman D'Amours]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from New Hampshire|U.S. House of Representatives]]

The '''Caja Navarra scandal''' unraveled in 2012 after the absorption of [[Caja Navarra]] (CAN), integrated in the financial conglomerate [[Banca Civica]], by [[CaixaBank]] (3 August 2012). [[Caja Navarra]] lost all its worth, causing its actual demise. Caja Navarra's acronym and brand CAN was kept converted into a foundation. The highly controversial crash of the institution gave way to a demand of responsibilities.
==Approach== [[File:CAN scandal.jpg|thumb|A closed Caja Navarra branch in [[San Sebastián]]]] [[File:Miguelsanz.jpg|thumb|Miguel Sanz, ex-president of Navarre]] [[Caja Navarra]] (CAN) is a merger of two entrenched savings banks renowned for their proximity to the Navarrese people, and considered a sign of identity, as well as a symbol of Navarre's economic solvency and autonomy. In the 1980s and 1990s, 43% of the money of the Navarrese was held in either of both institutions, representing the prime financial institution in [[Navarre]].
After the fusion of the savings banks Caja Provincial de Navarra and Caja de Ahorros Municipal de Pamplona in 2000, the re-founded institution undertook a series of financial operations and expansion of its branches out of Navarre (including a representative office in Washington). As a result, CAN's assets plummeted.
The savings bank became insolvent in 2012 after years of asset-stripping, including the mysterious disappearance of its artistic collection. The fallout of the scandal affected high- and mid-ranking officials of the regional party UPN ([[Unión del Pueblo Navarro]]) who held political and managerial positions both within the bank and the Government of Navarre.
==Mismanagement== In 2010 the Board of Founding Partners was established to insulate Caja Navarra from political meddling, but paradoxically it integrated well-known political personalities, all of them high-ranking members of UPN and PSN ([[Socialist Party of Navarre|Spanish Socialists in Navarre]]), such as [[Yolanda Barcina]], [[Miguel Sanz]], Alberto Catalán, Roberto Jimenez, or Enrique Maya<ref>{{cite video |people= |date=2013-06-25 |title=El gran golpe (The big sting)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DqXTZwdfLwE&feature=share |format= |medium= |language=Spanish |publisher=Ateak Ireki |location= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=2015-01-25|time=35’35|id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref> (mayor of Pamplona since 2011).
Caja Navarra-related societies of dubious operation came into being, such as Sociedad Industrial de CAN and HISCAN Patrimonio S.L. Their Permanent Board members, all of them high-ranking officials or ex-officials of the government of Navarre (UPN) and PSN, have come to be accused of receiving irregular bonuses. Only in 2011, the 16 permanent board members of HISCAN Patrimonio S.L. received 121,000 euros in bonuses, a period in which CAN incurred heavy financial losses estimated at 203 million euros in just one year, down from 500-plus millions’ worth, during Yolanda Barcina’s one-year tenure in the board.<ref>Ateak Ireki (2013), 37’18</ref>
It was revealed that Yolanda Barcina, Miguel Sanz, Álvaro Miranda, and Enrique Maya got paid 2,860 and 1,717 euros each for participating in one-hour meetings (two consecutively) of a ghostly Permanent Board, held 16 times.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date= |title=Caja Navarra pagó hasta 2.680 euros a cargos de UPN por reuniones de una hora |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2013/03/07/actualidad/1362683681_364258.html |newspaper=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=2015-01-31}}</ref> The meetings consisted of a financial briefing to the board members, in which no questions were made and no minutes were recorded. After the revelations, president of the region Yolanda Barcina claimed she would give the money back, while apologizing to the people of Navarre for her behaviour.
In the period extending from 2004 to 2011, the estimated figure in bonuses to representatives of political, social and cultural agencies affiliated to Caja Navarra (including Ricardo Martín Fluxa, a Spanish ex-Secretary of State for Security, or Javier Iturbe, PSN ex-president and member of the Board of Directors) amounted to 4,3 million euros.
==Parliamentary investigation== In late 2014, opposition parties of the [[Parliament of Navarre]] promoted the establishment of a parliamentary investigation panel to clear responsibilities. The [[Socialist Party of Navarre|Spanish Socialists' branch in Navarre]], the PSN, voiced its misgivings, while the party at the centre of the controversy, the anti-Basque UPN, showed a frontal refusal, arguing that the case had to be left to Justice, actually Madrid tribunals (a Supreme Court ruling had recently acquitted the president of Navarre Yolanda Barcina of legal misconduct in the scandal of Caja Navarra’s irregular bonuses).
However, a vote majority in the regional parliament made it possible the creation of that panel. Opposition parties ([[Geroa Bai]], [[EH Bildu]], [[Izquierda-Ezkerra]]) other than the Spanish Conservatives (PP) lashed out at the Socialists for attempting to constrain the range of topics to be addressed in the scrutiny, as well as allowing with their abstention to propel the party UPN, allegedly responsible for Caja Navarra's demise and main opponent to the parliamentary investigation, to chair the investigation panel and hold a critical position.
==See also== *[[Corruption in Navarre]]

[[China]]'s Cultural Heritage Day <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en/2006-06/05/content_82491.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060619173136/http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en/2006-06/05/content_82491.htm |archivedate=2006-06-19 |df= }}</ref> is one of the most important part of [[China]]’s culture contribution, the purpose of this Day is to create a good atmosphere of cultural heritage and to enhance the recognition about the importance of protecting heritage. In December 2005, the State Council issued Notice on Strengthening Cultural Heritage Protection, putting up specific requests on the protection of tangible and intangible cultural heritage. The [[China]]’s Cultural Heritage Day is a yearly event on the second Saturday in June. The Day was first celebrated on 10 June in 2006.

{{for|the insurgent group|Mullah Dadullah Front}} {{Hatnote|Not to be confused with the Pakistani Taliban leader [[Dadullah (Pakistani Taliban)|Dadullah]]}} {{Infobox military person | name = Dadullah Akhund
ملا دادالله آخوند | image = Mullah Dadullah.png | image_size = | birth_date = 1966{{cn|date=March 2017}} | death_date = May 13, 2007 (aged 41) | birth_place = [[Kandahar Province]], Afghanistan {{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2007/05/2008525184820173540.htmll|title=He was believed to have been born in Kandahar province|publisher=Aljazeera|date=13 May 2007}} | death_place = [[Helmand province]] | allegiance = [[File:Flag of Taliban.svg|25px]] [[Taliban]] | serviceyears = 1994–2007 | rank = [[Commander]] | battles = [[Soviet–Afghan War]]
[[War in Afghanistan (1978–present)|Afghan civil war]]
[[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]] | honorific-prefix = [[Mullah]] | term_start1 = | term_end1 = | party = [[Taliban]] | religion = [[Deobandi]] Sunni IslamDeobandi Islam: The Religion of the Taliban U. S. Navy Chaplain Corps, 15 October 2001 }} [[Maulavi]] or [[Mullah]] '''Dadullah''' or '''Dadullah Akhund''' ({{lang-ps|'''ملا دادالله آخوند'''}}) (1966 – May 13, 2007) was the [[Taliban]]'s senior military commander until he was killed by [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[United States|American]] [[special forces]] in [[Afghanistan]] in 2007.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070513/ap_on_re_as/afghan_commander_killed Yahoo News – Top Taliban Commander Killed In Fighting] He was an ethnic [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] from the [[Kakar]] tribe of [[Kandahar province]]. According to the [[United Nations]]' list of entities belonging to or associated with the Al-Qaida organization, he had been the Taliban's Minister of Construction.{{cite news|url=http://en.wikisource.org/w/index.php?title=Denied_Persons_Pursuant_to_UN_Security_Council_Resolution|title=Denied Persons Pursuant to UN Security Council Resolution |publisher=[[United States Federal Registry]]|author=[[John R. Bolton]]|year=2003|accessdate=November 3, 2010}} == Early life == Dadullah Belong Kakar Pashtun tribe ,He lost a leg when fighting with the [[Mujahideen]] against [[Soviet–Afghan War|Soviet occupation]] in the 1980s.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4998836.stm The Taleban's most feared commander], [[BBC News]], May 19, 2006 He was a member of the Taliban's 10-man leadership council before the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|US-led invasion in 2001]]. He was reportedly also a close aide to [[Mohammed Omar|Mullah Omar]]. In the period of 1999–2000, he led the suppression of a revolt by [[Hazaras]] in [[Bamyan Province|Bamyan]] province.[http://www.afgha.com/?q=en/node/520 The Specter of Mullah Dadullah] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060711021659/http://www.afgha.com/?q=en%2Fnode%2F520 |date=2006-07-11}}, [[afgha.com]] June 13, 2006 In January 2001, Dadullah's forces committed several massacres of ethnic Hazaras, resulting in the death of some 300 civilians in the [[Yakaolang]] area. On March 10, 2001, he supervised the destruction of the [[Buddhas of Bamiyan]], which had been ordered by Mullah Omar.{{cite book|last=Maley|first= William |title=The Afghanistan Wars|year=2002|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=978-0-333-80291-5|pages=240–241}} When the Taliban regime fell in December 2001, Dadullah escaped capture by [[United Islamic Front for the Salvation of Afghanistan|Northern Alliance]] forces in [[Kunduz province]]. == Fight post 2001 == Rumors that Dadullah may be headed to recapture the city with as many as 8,000 Taliban fighters, following the November 2001 [[Battle of Mazar-i-Sharif]], a thousand American ground forces were airlifted into the city.Khan, M. Ismail. ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'', [http://www.dawn.com/2001/11/10/top2.htm Mazar falls to Alliance: Taliban says they're regrouping], November 10, 2001 He allegedly participated (by giving orders via cell phone) in the murder of [[Ricardo Munguía (aid worker)|Ricardo Munguia]] on March 27, 2003. In 2005 he was sentenced ''in absentia'' to life in prison, along with three others, by [[Pakistan]] for the attempted murder of a member of Pakistan's parliament, [[Maulana Muhammad Khan Sherani]] of the [[Jamiat Ulema-i-Islam]] party. Sherani, an opponent of the Taliban, survived an [[Improvised explosive device|IED]] attack in his home constituency of [[Balochistan (Afghanistan)|Balochistan]] in November, 2004.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4566206.stm Fugitive Taleban leader sentenced], ''[[BBC News]]'', December 29, 2005 A "Western intelligence source" claimed Dadullah may have been operating out of [[Quetta]], Pakistan.[https://www.theguardian.com/afghanistan/story/0,,1784304,00.html Across the border from Britain's troops, Taliban rises again], ''[[The Guardian]]'', May 27, 2006 Others, including the Pakistani government, claimed he was operating near [[Kandahar]], Afghanistan. In 2006, he claimed to have 12,000 men and control 20 districts in the former Taliban heartland in the southern provinces of Kandahar, [[Helmand Province|Helmand]], [[Zabul Province|Zabul]] and [[Orūzgān Province|Orūzgān]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/5029190.stm Afghanistan: Taleban's second coming], [[BBC News]], June 2, 2006 Dadullah had reportedly been a central figure in the recruitment of Pakistani nationals to the Taliban and was also one of the main Taliban spokesmen, frequently meeting with Al-Jazeera television reporters.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1148482062130&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Captured Taliban leader appears on Al-Jazeera], ''[[Jerusalem Post]]'', May 29, 2006 In the summer of 2006, he was reportedly sent by Mullah Omar to [[South Waziristan]] to convince local Pashtun insurgents to agree to a [[Waziristan Accord|truce with Pakistan]].[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/24/wafg24.xml Omar role in truce reinforces fears that Pakistan 'caved in' to Taliban], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', September 24, 2006 In October 2006 it was rumored[http://www.thenation.com/doc/20061030/parenti_video Taliban Rising], ''[[The Nation]]'', October 12, 2006 that the Afghan government was considering giving control of its defense ministry over to Dadullah as part of a reconciliation plan with the Taliban to stop the ongoing insurgency. Mullah Dadullah was linked to massacres of Shi'a, the scorched earth policy of Shi'a villages in 2001 (which he boasted about once on the radio), and the summary execution of men suspected of throwing hand grenades into his compound in 2001 (they were hanged at one of the main roundabouts). According to an interview he gave to the [[BBC]], he had hundreds of [[Suicide attack|suicide bombers]] waiting for his orders to launch an offensive against [[NATO]] troops.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6650755.stm Afghan Taleban commander killed], [[BBC News]], May 13, 2007 Dadullah oversaw Taliban negotiations for the hostage-taking of Italian reporter [[Daniele Mastrogiacomo]] and his two Afghan assistants in March 2007. Mastrogiacomo's driver was later beheaded. Mastrogiacomo was reportedly exchanged for five senior Taliban leaders, including Ustad Yasir, Abdul Latif Hakimi, Mansoor Ahmad, a brother of Dadullah, and two commanders identified as Hamdullah and Abdul Ghaffar. The Taliban threatened to kill the interpreter Ajmal Naqshbandi, one of the two Afghan assistants, on March 29, 2007, unless the [[Kabul]] government freed two Taliban prisoners.[http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUKL293332420070329 Taliban leader threatens to kill Afghan hostage], ''[[Reuters]], March 29, 2007 Ajmal was later beheaded after the Afghan government refused to free anymore Taliban prisoners. According to [[Asadullah Khalid]], the governor of [[Kandahar Province]], "Mullah Dadullah was the backbone of the Taliban. He was a brutal and cruel commander who killed and beheaded Afghan civilians."[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/05/13/wafgh113.xml Top Taliban commander killed in Afghanistan], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', May 13, 2007 == Death == Afghan officials reported on May 13, 2007, that Mullah Dadullah was killed the previous evening in a raid by U.S, Afghan and NATO forces, known to have included the [[Special Boat Service]] (SBS), a British special forces unit, in Helmand Province, after he left his "sanctuary" for a meeting with fellow commanders, in southern Afghanistan.[http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/politics/international_politics/taliban+commander+mullah+dadullah+killed/510372 Taliban commander Mullah Dadullah killed], ''[[Channel 4]]'', May 13, 2007 Some reports indicate Dadullah was killed in the Gershk district, while others claim he was killed near the Sangin and Nari Saraj district.{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2007/05/mullah_dadullah_tali.php|title=Mullah Dadullah, Taliban top commander, killed in Helmand|publisher=Long War Journal}} [[Asadullah Khalid]], the governor of Kandahar province, put the body of Dadullah on display at his official residence. The body appeared to have three bullet wounds, two in the torso and one in the back of the head. The Taliban named [[Mullah Bakht]], Dadullah's younger brother, as his replacement.[http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2007/05/14/taliban-replacement.html Taliban Names Replacement After Death of Top Commander], [[CBC News]], May 14, 2007 On June 7, 2007, the Taliban said that Dadullah's body had been returned to them, in exchange for four Afghan health ministry workers who had been held hostage, and had been buried by his family in Kandahar. The Taliban said that a fifth hostage had been beheaded because Dadullah's body was not returned quickly enough.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6729343.stm "Taleban handed commander's body"], BBC News, June 7, 2007.[http://blogs.abcnews.com/theblotter/2007/06/afghan_trade_fo.html The Blotter: Afghan Trade: Four Hostages for Body of Dead Taliban] == See also == * [[Mullah Dadullah Front]] == References == {{Wikisource|Dadullah interview with as- Sahab}} {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Taliban leaders]] [[Category:Afghan Islamists]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Afghan guerrillas killed in action]] [[Category:Pashtun people]] [[Category:1960s births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Salafi jihadists]]

'''Fellow of the American Society of Genealogists''' (FASG) is an independent society of fellows reflecting the master class of genealogists within the United States of America. There are only fifty (50) lifetime FASG members within the [[American Society of Genealogists]] (ASG).<ref name=FASG1>{{Cite web |accessdate=March 1, 2015 |url=http://fasg.org/ |title=Fellows of The American Society of Genealogists |author=The American Society of Genealogists |work= |publisher=[[American Society of Genealogists]] |year=2015}}</ref>
Fellows have the post-nominal initials FASG following their surnames. Fellows embody and promote the highest standards of genealogical scholarship.<ref name=FASG1/>
==History== At the time of the ASG founding, there was no certification process or standard for competent genealogists. The [[American Society of Genealogists]] (ASG) founded in 1940 created a method to honor significant achievement in the genealogical field by 1944. Those meeting the standards of excellence are nominated and voted for within the ASG after a vacancy occurs.<ref name=FASG1/>
==Criteria for nomination== Potential FASG members are reviewed for the following criteria.<ref name=FASG1/>
*The quality of published work. *Compiled genealogies. *Demonstration to effectively "use primary source material; to evaluate and analyze data; to properly document evidence; and to reach sound, logical conclusions presented in a clear and proper manner."
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://fasg.org/fellows/current-fellows/ List of Current Fellows] * [http://fasg.org/ Official website.]

{{other uses}} {{infobox organization |name = The Harmonie Club |image = Harmonie Club 1905.JPG |image_border = |size = 250px |caption = The club's [[Stanford White]] designed facade |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = {{Start date|1852|10|16}} |extinction = |type = [[Social Club]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = 4 East 60th Street |location = [[New York, New York]] |region_served = [[New York metropolitan area]] |coords = {{coord|40.764665|N|73.97212|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = Robert H. Werbel |main_organ = |parent organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.harmonieclub.org harmonieclub.org] |remarks = |former name = Gesellschaft Harmonie }}
'''The Harmonie Club''' is a [[gentlemen's club|private social club]] in [[New York City]]. Founded in 1852, the club is the second oldest social club in New York.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/2007/05/08/men-clubs-private-forbeslife-cx_hp_07networks_0509clubs.html Elite Membership Clubs Get A Makeover]</ref> It is located at 4 East 60th Street, in a building designed by [[Stanford White]].
==History== Originally named the Gesellschaft Harmonie, the club was founded on October 16, 1852 by N. Gutman, M. Werner, H. Beer, Herman Cohn, Charles Werner, and Sigmund Werner. Although prominent [[German Jews]], the group was reportedly denied admission to the [[Union Club of the City of New York|Union Club]], which had a tacit policy of [[discrimination]]. The club's original charter provided that it was created to provide "mutually beneficial entertainment, occasional singing entertainments, lectures, etc" for recent German immigrants. The first meeting of the club was held November 8, 1852 in a rented room on Broome Street with thirty-nine members in attendance. Between 1852 and 1867, the burgeoning club was regularly moved as the membership outgrew each rented space. After this nomadic period the club purchased land at 45 West Forty-Second Street to erect a permanent location and raised enough funds to have architect [[Henry Fernbach]] design the building. Later, this building was refurbished and had an annex added, both of which were designed by [[Henry Beaumont Herts|Herts and Tallant]], architects of the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music]] and Coram Library at [[Bates College]].
The growth of the club was supported through dues and the creation of a nomination process to accept new members. To govern the organization, the club held monthly meetings run by elected officers. During the first ten years of existence the group held balls, lectures, and other social events throughout New York City. The tenth anniversary was celebrated on October 18, 1863 with a banquet and ball attended by over one hundred and fifty members. Two years later the club was incorporated as, "The Harmonie Social Club of the City of New York", with two re-incorporations in 1867 and 1894. The first re-incorporation altered the provisions to allow the club to own property and the building on Forty-Second Street. The latter reincorporation was to change the name to "The Harmonie Club." Members, however, continued to use the former name, Gesellschaft Harmonie, until 1893 when the club adopted English as its official language in place of German. The club was so successful, that by 1884 the ''[[New York Times]]'' reported that "many of New-York's leading German citizens are connected" with it.
The large building erected on West Forty-Second allowed the Harmonie Club to host in-house events, and for the next forty years the club regularly scheduled events such as dances, lectures, concerts, theatrical performances, billiards, cards, and bowling. In 1891, the Admission Committee was created, removing the task of approving and voting on new members from the general monthly meetings. The turn of the century brought several changes to the club. These changes included the first events for non-married members, a declining interest in large social gatherings such as dances, and increasing property taxes along Forty-Second Street. [[File:Harmonie Club 1867.JPG|thumb|right|42nd Street Location]]
In response to these pressures, a decision was made to relocate to a more suitable building. The club solicited donations from its members to build a new clubhouse on property acquired on the [[Upper East Side]]. In December 1905, the club moved into new premises at Four East 60th Street, in a building designed by renowned [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux Arts]] architect, [[Stanford White]] of [[McKim, Meade & White]]. Lighting for the building was provided by [[Edward F. Caldwell & Co.]] Later alterations, inside and out, were designed by [[Benjamin Wistar Morris, III|Benjamin Wistar Morris]].<ref>White, Norval & Willensky, Elliot. ''[[AIA Guide to New York City]]'' (Fourth Edition). New York:Three Rivers Press, 2000. {{ISBN|0-8129-3107-6}}</ref> A banquet to celebrate the opening was attended by over four hundred members. [[image:Harmonie-club.jpg|thumb|right|Current Location]] [[image:Harmonieclub.jpg|250px|thumb|right|A Stanford White drawing of the facade]]
In 1914, to meet the changing interests of its members, the Harmonie Club purchased the North Shore Country Club on Long Island. According to an April 1914 President's Report: "The trend of time is toward the country club and healthy outdoor activity. With the increasing tendency to spread the weekends in suburban surrounding, with the increased use of the automobile, and with the increased desire for outdoor exercise, especially on the part of the younger generation." After several years of renovation the country club opened for Harmonie Club members only. This arrangement was designed to both serve and increase interest in the parent organization. Over the years, the North Shore Country Club has hosted several tournaments. Although no longer affiliated with the club, [http://nsccli.com North Shore] still operates today as a private course.
The growth of the Harmonie Club was slowed by the outbreak of World War I and related anti-German sentiment, as well as, the wartime service of current and potential members. The club supported the United States' campaign through hosting events for enlisted men and their families. In addition, fifty of the club's members served in the war effort. Following the war, the club prospered reaching a record high of eight hundred and fifty members in 1929. This number was cut in half by 1934 with the onset of the [[Great Depression]]. The Board of Governors began a large scale renovation of the building on Sixtieth Street under the expertise of architect Benjamin Morris in the late 1930s. The new facilities along with a series of changes in the club's bylaws were designed to modernize the organization and attracted a large number of new and young members.
With its origins as a Jewish club, for several years it served as the meeting location for the [[American Jewish Committee]], especially in the tumultuous 1930s.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00815FF3E5C1B7A93C7A9178ED85F4C8385F9 | title = Jewish Ranks Split on U.S. Plebiscite — American Committee to Take Up Congress Plan Next Week | publisher = New York Times | date = 1938-05-05 | accessdate = 2008-09-16}}</ref> The committee took a leading role in resettling refugees from the Nazis and in ensuring their contribution to the Allied war effort. Albert Einstein and other prominent Anti-Nazi figures of the day sponsored events at the club to raise awareness of the Nazis' persecution of the Jews. The growth of the Club was halted in 1941 with the American entry into World War II. The club continued to operate throughout the war and resumed its philanthropic programs from World War I, such as hosting functions for enlisted men. Following the war, the Club's membership returned to pre-Depression numbers.
===Recent events=== Over the years its political role in the community appeared to have moderated, and it became more of a social center, as well as extending its membership to include non-German Jews and others. In 1987, it was the location of the world's 'most charitable' bridge game, which raised $62,000.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE7D61E38F930A15756C0A961948260 | title = Bridge; A Record $62,000 Is Raised At a Harmonie Club Event | publisher = New York Times | first = Alan | last = Truscott | date = 1987-05-23 | accessdate = 2008-09-16}}</ref> Historically known as a Jewish club, the club has indicated a willingness to broaden its membership. Nonetheless, a perceived lack of diversity caused member [[Michael Bloomberg]] to resign in 2001, in anticipation of his initial mayoral run.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE7D91438F932A05756C0A963958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=print | title = Where the Diner Is the Star | first = Elaine | last = Louie | publisher = New York Times | date = 1995-05-31 | accessdate = 2008-09-16}}</ref>
As a New York cultural institution, the Harmonie Club has been host to numerous political and cultural luminaries in recent years, including a visit and address from former U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]] in 2007, presentations or panel discussions with Senators [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Chuck Schumer]], Representative [[Charles Rangel]], every New York mayor and governor since Mayor [[Robert F. Wagner Jr.]], and Governor [[Herbert H. Lehman]].
