Koreans working in S’wak legally|author1=Sharon Ling|author2=Stephen Then|author3=Yu Ji|author4=Andy Chua|author5=Neville Spykerman|publisher= The Star (Malaysia)|date=24 November 2014|accessdate=12 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="nk2">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/24/-sp-north-korea-malaysia-mine-labour|title=North Koreans are needed to do the dangerous jobs, says Malaysia|author=Kate Hodal|publisher=The Guardian (UK)|date=24 November 2014|accessdate=12 April 2016}}</ref>|langs = [[Korean language|Korean]], [[English language|English]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Malay language|Malay]]<ref name="TheStar2">{{citation|title=Great chance to mix|url=http://thestar.com.my/education/story.asp?file=/2006/7/16/education/14828745|date=16 July 2006|accessdate=2 May 2007|periodical=The Star|last=|first=}}</ref> |rels = [[Mahayana Buddhism]],<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.buddhanet.info/wbd/search.php?keyword=korean+&prev_keyword%5B%5D=korean&newsearch=new&search=Begin+Search&country_id=48&province_id=0|periodical=World Buddhist Directory|publisher=Buddha Dharma Education Association|title=Korean Buddhist congregations in Malaysia|year=2006|accessdate=9 March 2009}}</ref> [[Christianity]]<ref name="TheStar">{{cite news|title=Feeling at home in Malaysia|url=http://thestar.com.my/education/story.asp?file=/2006/7/16/education/14728091|last=Tan|first=Ee Loo|date=16 July 2006|accessdate=4 May 2007|work=The Star|publisher=Malaysia}}</ref> and [[Islam]] minorities |related-c = [[Korean diaspora]] }}
'''Koreans in Malaysia''' numbered 12,690 individuals {{asof|2015|lc=on}}, making them the 22nd-largest community of [[Korean diaspora|overseas Koreans]], and the 5th-largest in [[Southeast Asia]].<ref name="MOFAT"/>
==Migration history== The history of Koreans in Malaysia goes back almost half a century; [[Malaysia – South Korea relations|Malaysia and South Korea]] established [[diplomatic relations]] in 1960, and in the following decade, when Malaysia faced a shortage of doctors, a number of foreign doctors, including Koreans and Filipinos, were authorised to practise in Malaysia.<ref>{{Citation|year=1970|last=Henderson|first=John William|title=Area Handbook for Malaysia|publisher=American University|oclc=154312|page=151}}</ref><ref name="Bernama">{{cite news|last=Ariffin|first=Roslan|date=8 March 2007|accessdate=4 May 2007|title=Najib Dijangka Kukuhkan Hubungan Dua Hala M'sia-Korea Selatan (Najib plans strong Malaysia-South Korea bilateral relations)|work=Bernama|url=http://bernama.com.my/bernama/v3/bm/news.php?id=250285|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929102907/http://bernama.com.my/bernama/v3/bm/news.php?id=250285|archivedate=29 September 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Some construction workers, pilots, and sailors were also sent to the country.<ref>{{Citation|title=Immigrant Entrepreneurs: Koreans in Los Angeles, 1965–1982|first=Edna|last=Bonacich |author2=Light, Ivan|publisher=University of California Press|location=United States|pages=104|year=1991|isbn=0-520-07656-7}}</ref>
==Demography and distribution== [[File:Korean shop at Singgah Mata Street, Kota Kinabalu.jpg|thumb|left|Korean shop at Singgah Mata Street, [[Kota Kinabalu]], Sabah.]] The Korean community in Malaysia consist mostly of migrants working in [[List of South Korean companies|South Korean companies]], as well as an increasing number of [[international student]]s.<ref name="Yonhap">{{cite news|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/Engnews/20070131/480100000020070131080009E3.html|title=Malaysia emerging as destination for Korean students seeking global education|last=Kim|first=Hyun|work=Yonhap News|date=31 January 2007|accessdate=4 May 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070331120512/http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/Engnews/20070131/480100000020070131080009E3.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 31 March 2007}}</ref> The number of retirees coming under the [[Malaysia My Second Home]] immigration programme has also been increasing.<ref name="Phoon"/> Most Korean residents are concentrated in [[Kuala Lumpur]] and [[Selangor]], especially in [[Ampang Jaya|Ampang]], where a [[Koreatown]] is beginning to sprout.<ref name="Rhee">{{cite news|last=Rhee|first=Hyun Ah|title=Koreans find green pastures in Ampang|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/rentakini/61135|work=Malaysiakini|date=18 December 2006|accessdate=4 May 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070124232654/http://www.malaysiakini.com/rentakini/61135 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 24 January 2007}}</ref> The [[Korean Wave|popularity of Korean dramas]] in Malaysia has meant an increasingly friendly reception for Korean migrants by local people.<ref name="Yonhap"/> Real estate investment is another factor drawing Koreans to migrate to Malaysia, due to the taxes imposed on people who own more than two properties in Korea; Malaysia is the second most popular market for overseas real estate investment by Koreans, after the United States.<ref name="Phoon"/>
Around 200,000 South Korean tourists came to Malaysia in 2006; [[Kota Kinabalu]] was their most popular destination.<ref name="Bernama"/> About 1,800 to 2,000 Koreans reside in [[Sabah]], most of them in Kota Kinabalu.<ref name="NewSabahTimes"/> Sabah Oil and Gas Terminal project in [[Kimanis]], Papar has brought South Korean employees of [[Samsung Engineering]] to work and live there until the terminal completion in December 2013.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.samsungengineering.co.kr/eng/sustain/PressReleasesView.jsp?tb2_seq=308&category=14|title=Samsung Engineering officially signs the Sabah Oil & Gas Terminal Project|publisher=Samsung Engineering|date=18 October 2010|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref>
There were also some North Koreans working in Sarawak in the mine industry.<ref name="nk1"/> This was revealed after [[2014 Selantik coal mine explosion|a tragedy]] that killed one and injuring seven others North Koreans in 2014.<ref name="nk2"/> By September 2017, the state Immigration Department has confirmed there is no more North Koreans working in Sarawak with the [[coal mine]] also had stopped their operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nst.com.my/news/nation/2017/09/282406/all-north-koreans-sarawak-have-been-sent-back|title=All North Koreans in Sarawak have been sent back|author=Adib Povera|publisher=New Straits Times|date=21 September 2017|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref>
==Education== Roughly 2,000 of the Koreans in Malaysia are students; Malaysia's multicultural environment offers them the chance to practise English as well as study other languages such as [[Chinese language|Chinese]] or [[Malay language|Malay]]; they describe the educational environment as being more relaxed than in Korea. [[Christianity in Korea|Korean churches]] form an important part of their social life.<ref name="TheStar2"/><ref name="TheStar"/> Their parents also prefer Malaysia to other countries for several reasons. The low cost of living and [[education in Malaysia]] is a major pull factor; Parents also believe Malaysia offers a better environment for English study than neighbouring countries, as prevalence of [[Islam in Malaysia]] means that the nightlife is less of a distraction. A representative from one [[Seoul]] company which helps to arrange overseas study for local students estimated that 90% of Korean students going to [[Southeast Asia]] choose Malaysia as their destination. However, some [[international school]]s have stopped accepting Korean students because they have become too large a proportion of their student bodies.<ref name="Yonhap"/> In many cases, mothers come to Malaysia with their young school-age children, while the breadwinning father remains behind in South Korea and sends money to support them.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/eastasia/view/409393/1/.html|periodical=Channel News Asia|title=Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia: Weakening Korean won forces South Koreans to give up overseas plans|last=Lim|first=Yun-suk|date=17 February 2009|accessdate=29 April 2009}}</ref>
Malaysia's first officially registered weekend school for Korean nationals, the Malaysia Korean School, was established on 7 December 1974; it had 26 teachers and enrolled 148 students {{As of|2006|lc=on}}. It was located on [[Jalan Ampang]] in Kuala Lumpur.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_informal_inform.htm?no=731&page=7&key=2|title=Overseas Korean Educational Institutions|chapter=재말레이시아한인학교|publisher=International Institute for Education Development, Republic of Korea|year=2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108134903/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_informal_inform.htm?no=731&page=7&key=2|archivedate=8 January 2008|accessdate=31 December 2009}}</ref> The first day school for Korean families, the [[Korean School of Malaysia]], opened in [[Cyberjaya]] in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2016/05/27/6/0302000000AEN20160527006200315F.html|title=Malaysia's first Korean school to open in September |publisher=''[[Yonhap News]]''|date=2016-05-27|accessdate=2018-10-15}}</ref>

icon}} | related-c = [[Mingrelians]], [[Svan people|Svans]] and other groups of [[Georgians|Kartvelians]] | footnotes = | }} {{Laz people}} The '''Laz people''' or '''Lazi''' ({{lang-lzz|Lazi, ლაზი}}; {{lang-ka|ლაზი, lazi; or ჭანი, ch'ani}}; {{lang-tr|Laz}}) are an indigenous [[Kartvelian languages|Kartvelian]]-speaking [[ethnic group]]{{cite book|title=An Ethnohistorical Dictionary of the Russian and Soviet Empires|author=[[James S. Olson]]|publisher=Greenwood|year=1994|editors=Lee Brigance Pappas, Nicholas Charles Pappas|page=436}} inhabiting the [[Black Sea]] coastal regions of [[Black Sea Region|Turkey]] and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].1 Minorsky, V. "Laz." Encyclopaedia of Islam, Second Edition. Edited by: P. Bearman , Th. Bianquis , C.E . Bosworth , E. van Donzel and W.P. Heinrichs. Brill, 2010. Estimates of the total population of the Laz people today vary drastically, with numbers as low as 45,000 to as high as 1.6 million people, with the majority living in northeast Turkey. The Laz speak the [[Laz language]], a member of the same Kartvelian [[language family]] as [[Georgian language|Georgian]], [[Svan language|Svan]], and [[Mingrelian language|Mingrelian]].{{cite book |last=Dalby |first=A. |year=2002 |title=Language in Danger; The Loss of Linguistic Diversity and the Threat to Our Future |publisher=Columbia University Press|page=38}}BRAUND, D., Georgia in antiquity: a history of Colchis and Transcaucasian Iberia 550 BC – AD 562, Oxford University Press, p. 93 The Laz language is classified as endangered by [[UNESCO]], with an estimated 130,000 to 150,000 speakers in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/languages-atlas/en/atlasmap/language-id-1056.html |title=World Language Atlas |publisher=[[UNESCO]]|accessdate=31 January 2015}} == Etymology == The ancestors of the Laz people are cited by many classical authors from [[Scylax of Caryanda|Scylax]] to [[Procopius]] and [[Agathias]], but the Laz ({{lang-el|Λαζοί|}}) themselves are cited by [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] around the 2nd century BC,Pliny, NH 6.4.12Braund (1994), p. 157, fn. 24. The ethnonym "Laz" is unhesitatingly linked to a [[Svan language|Svan]] toponym La-zan (i.e. La = territorial prefix + [[Zan languages|Zan]]). By the 6th century, the Colchians of [[Pontus (region)|Pontus]] were known as the [[Zans|Tzanni]] ({{lang-grc|Τζάννοι}}), at the same time when the [[Caucasus|Caucasian]] state of Lazica (or [[Lazica|Egrisi]] in Georgian sources) existed on the [[Rioni River|Phasis valley]] basin. According to Procopius, the [[List of Byzantine emperors|Byzantine emperor]] [[Justinian I]] subdued Tzanni in the 520s and converted them to [[Christianity]].[[Procopius]] ''Bell. Pers''. i. 15, ''Bell. Goth''. iv. 2, ''de Aed.'' iii. 6. When the ancient [[Metropolis (religious jurisdiction)|metropolis]], [[Poti|Phasis]], was lost by the Byzantine Empire, [[Trabzon|Trebizond]] became the [[Metropolitan bishop]] of Lazica, since then the name Lazi appears the general Greek name for the southern Colchian tribes ({{lang-el|Τζανοί|Tzanoi}}) lying outside of the direct control of the Lazic Kingdom. The Pontic Lazi, which were incorporated within the [[Byzantine Empire]], and differed from the Caucasian Lazi, or [[Mingrelians|Megrelians]], have retained the old name "Lazi" till today. == Origins == The Laz are ethnically a branch of the [[Georgians]]. Many modern theories suggest that the ancestors of the Laz-[[Mingrelians]] constituted the dominant ethnic and cultural presence in the south-eastern [[Black Sea]] region in antiquity, and hence played a significant role in the ethnogenesis of the modern Georgians.Miniature Empires: A Historical Dictionary of the Newly Independent States, James Minahan, p. 116Cyril Toumanoff, Studies in Christian Caucasian History, p 80 ==History== {{main|History of the Laz people}} === Antiquity === [[File:Colchis and Iberia, VI-III centuries B.C..jpg|left|thumb|Ancient Georgian states of [[Colchis]] and [[Caucasian Iberia|Iberia]], 500–400 BC]] In the 13th century [[Common Era|BC]], the Kingdom of [[Colchis]] was formed as a result of the increasing consolidation of the tribes inhabiting the region, which covered modern western Georgia and [[Turkey]]'s north-eastern provinces of [[Trabzon Province|Trabzon]] and [[Rize Province|Rize]]. In 8th century, several Greek [[Colonies in antiquity|trading colonies]] were established along the shores of the [[Black Sea]].[[File:MÖ_6._yüzyıla_ait_gümüş_Kolkhis_sikkesi.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:M%C3%96_6._y%C3%BCzy%C4%B1la_ait_g%C3%BCm%C3%BC%C5%9F_Kolkhis_sikkesi.jpg|right|thumb|220x220px|[[Colchis|Colchian]] silver coin, 6th century BC.]]By the 6th century BC, the tribes living in the southern Colchis ([[Macrones]], [[Mushki|Moschi]], [[Marres]] etc.) were incorporated into the [[nineteenth Satrapy]] of [[Achaemenid Empire|Persia]]. The Achaemenid Empire was defeated by [[Alexander the Great]], however following of Alexander's death a number of separate kingdoms were established in [[Anatolia]], including [[Pontus (region)|Pontus]], in the corner of the south-eastern [[Black Sea]], ruled by [[Mithridates I of Pontus|Mithridates]]. The very small number of Hellenistic Greek inscriptions that have been found anywhere in Pontus suggest that [[Culture of Greece|Greek culture]] did not substantially penetrate beyond the coastal cities and the court.http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/pontus As a result of the brilliant [[Mithridatic Wars|Roman campaigns]] led by the generals [[Pompey]] and [[Lucullus]], the kingdom of Pontus was completely destroyed by the [[Roman Empire|Romans]] and all its territory, including Colchis, was incorporated into the Roman Empire. The former southern provinces of Colchis were reorganized into the [[Roman province]] of [[Pontus (region)|Pontus Polemoniacus]], while the northern Cholchis became the Roman province of [[Lazica|Lazicum]]. By the mid-3rd century, the Lazi tribe came to dominate most of Colchis, establishing the kingdom of [[Lazica]]. [[Colonies in antiquity|Greek colonization]] was restricted to the coast, and in later ages [[Roman Empire|Roman control]] remained likewise only nominal over the tribes of the interior.{{harvnb|Talbert|2000|p=1226}}. The coastal regions, however, belonged to the Roman province of [[Pontus (region)|Pontus Polemoniacus]]. === Middle Ages === [[File:Lazica in Late Antiquity.svg|left|thumb|The kingdom of Lazica in Late Antiquity|220x220px]] During the reign of the [[List of Byzantine emperors|Byzantine emperor]] [[Justinian I]] ({{Circa}} 527–565) the warlike tribes of the interior Pontus, called [[Sanni|Sannoi]] or [[Macrones|Tzannoi]], the ancestors of modern Laz people, were subdued, [[Christianization|Christianized]] and brought to central rule.{{harvnb|Evans|2000|p=93}}. Locals began to have closer contact with the Greeks and acquired various [[Culture of Greece|Hellenic]] cultural traits, including in some cases the language. [[File:Map of the Caucasus, 740 CE.svg|thumb|Map of the Caucasus c. 740]] From 542 to 562, Lazica was a scene of the protracted rivalry between the [[Byzantine Empire|Eastern Roman]] and [[Sasanian Empire|Sassanid]] empires, culminating in the [[Lazic War]]. Emperor [[Heraclius]]'s offensive in 628 AD brought victory over the Persians and ensured Roman predominance in Lazica until the invasion and conquest of the Caucasus by the [[Rashidun Caliphate|Arabs]] in the second half of the 7th century. In the 7th century Lazica fell to the [[Arab rule in Georgia|Muslim conquest]], however in the 8th century combined Lazic and [[Abasgoi|Abasgian]] forces successfully repelled the Arab occupation. In 780 Lazica was incorporated to [[kingdom of Abkhazia]] via a dynastic union, the latter led the unification of [[Kingdom of Georgia|Georgian monarchy]] in the 11th century, thus ousting the Pontic Lazs from western Georgia; thereafter, the Lazs lived under nominal Byzantine suzerainty in the [[Theme (Byzantine district)|theme]] of [[Chaldia]], with its capital at [[Trabzon|Trebizond]], governed by the native semi-autonomous rulers, like the [[Gabras]] family.Hewsen, 47 According to the 10th century [[Arabs|Arab]] geographer [[Abu'l-Fida|Abul Feda]] city of Trebizond was regarded as being largely a Lazian port. Following the [[Seljuq dynasty|Seljuk Turks]] invasion, there has been continuous influx of [[Armenians]] resulting partial armenization of the local Tzan population and formation of new [[Hemshin peoples|Hemshin]] identity.Simonian. "Hamshen Before Hemshin", pp. 21-22. [[File:Trebizond1300.png|thumb|Map of the [[Empire of Trebizond|Trebizond Empire]] in Anatolia, AD 1300.]] With the [[Georgian expedition to Chaldia|Georgian intervention in Chaldia]] and [[Fourth Crusade|collapse of Byzantine Empire]] in 1204, [[Empire of Trebizond]] was established along the southwestern coast of the Black Sea, populated by a large Lazian-speaking population.Mikaberidze, A. (2015). Historical dictionary of Georgia. 2nd ed. Lanham, MD, United States: ROWMAN & LITTLEFIELD, p.634. In the eastern part of the same empire, an autonomous coastal theme of [[Lazia (Pontus)|Greater Lazia]] was established.Thys-Şenocak, Lucienne. ''Ottoman Women Builders''. Aldershot, England: Ashgate, 2006. Byzantine authors, such as [[George Pachymeres|Pachymeres]], and to some extent Trapezuntines such as [[John Lazaropoulos|Lazaropoulos]] and [[Basilios Bessarion|Bessarion]], regarded the Trapezuntian Empire as being no more than a Lazian border state.Bryer 1967, 179. Though Greek in higher culture, the rural areas of Trebizond empire appear to have been predominantly Laz in ethnic composition.[https://www.encyclopedia.com/humanities/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/laz Encyclopedia of World Cultures, Laz] Laz family names, with [[Hellenization|Hellenized]] terminations, are noticeable in the records of the mediaeval empire of Trebizond, and it is perhaps not too venturesome to suggest that the [[Trapezuntine Civil War|antagonism]] between the "town-party" and the "country-party," which existed in the politics of "the Empire," was in fact a national antagonism of Laz against Greek. In 1282, [[Siege of Trebizond (1282)|kingdom of Imereti besieged Trebizond]], however after the failed attempt to take the city, the Georgians occupied several provinces and all the Trebizontine province of Lazia threw off its allegiance to the king of the 'Iberian' and 'Lazian' tribes and united itself with the Georgian [[Kingdom of Imereti]]. === Early Modern era === {{further|Hellenization of Laz people}}[[File:Sanjak of Lazistan, Ottoman Anatolia, 1914.png|thumb|[[Lazistan Sanjak|Sanjak of Lazistan]], Ottoman Anatolia, 1914|250x250px|left]]Laz populated area was often contested by different Georgian principalities, however through [[Battle of Murjakheti]] (1535), [[Principality of Guria]] finally ensured control over it, until 1547, when it was conquered by resurgent [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] forces and reorganized into the [[Lazistan Sanjak|Lazistan sanjak]] as part of [[eyalet]] of [[Trebizond Eyalet|Trabzon]]. After the Ottoman [[Siege of Trebizond (1461)|conquest of Trebizond Empire]] and later [[Ottoman invasion of Guria]] in 1547, Ottomans fought for three centuries to [[Three Hundred Laz Martyrs|destroy]] the Christian-Georgian consciousness of the Laz people. Local orthodox inhabitants, once subordinated to the [[Georgian Orthodox Church]], had to obey [[Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople|Patriarchate of Constantinople]]. Part of the native population were target of the Ottoman [[Islamization]] policy and gradually converted to [[Islam]], while the second part of the people who remained orthodox subordinated to the [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek Church]], thus gradually becoming [[Pontic Greeks|Greeks]], the process known as [[Hellenization of Laz people]]. Lazs who were under the control of Constantinople, soon lost their language and self-identity as they became Greeks and learned Greek, especially [[Pontic Greek|Pontic dialect]] of [[Greek language]], although native language was preserved by Lazs who had become Muslims. Not only the [[Pasha]]s (governors) of Trabzon until the 19th century, but real authority in many of the ''[[Kaza|cazas]]'' (districts) of each sanjak by the mid-17th century lay in the hands of relatively independent native Laz [[derebey]]s ("valley-lords"), or feudal chiefs who exercised absolute authority in their own districts, carried on petty warfare with each other, did not owe allegiance to a superior and never paid contributions to the sultan. This state of insubordination was not really broken until the assertion of Ottoman authority during the reforms of the [[Osman Nuri Pasha|Osman Pasha]] in 1850s. In 1547, Ottomans built coastal fortress of [[Gonio Fortress|Gonia]], an important Ottoman outpost in southwestern Georgia,{{cite book|url=http://dspace.nplg.gov.ge/bitstream/1234/3067/1/Istoria_Carstva_Gruzinskogo.pdf|last=Bagrationi|first=Vakhushti|publisher=Metsniereba|year=1976|editor=Nakashidze, N.T.|location=Tbilisi|pages=133–135|language=ru|script-title=ru:История Царства Грузинского|trans-title=History of the Kingdom of Georgia|authorlink=Prince Vakhushti of Kartli}}{{cite thesis|last=Church|first=Kenneth|title=From dynastic principality to imperial district: the incorporation of Guria into the Russian Empire to 1856|date=2001|publisher=University of Michigan|type=Ph.D.|pages=127–129}} which served as capital of Lazistan; then [[Batumi|Batum]] until it was acquired by the Russians in 1878, throughout the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)|Russo-Turkish War]], thereafter, [[Rize]] became the capital of the sanjak. The Muslim Lazs living near the war zones in [[Batum Oblast|Batumi Oblast]] were subjected to ethnic cleansing; many Lazes living in Batumi fled to the Ottoman Empire, settling along the southern Black Sea coast to the east of [[Samsun]] and [[Marmara Region|Marmara region]]. [[File:AsiaMinor1910.jpg|thumb|Ethnic map of Asia Minor, 1910.]] Around 1914 Ottoman policy towards the Christian population shifted; state policy was since focused to the forceful migration of Christian [[Pontic Greeks|Pontic Greek]] and Laz population living in coastal areas, close to the [[Caucasus Campaign|Turkish-Russian front]] to the Anatolian hinterland. In the 1920s Christian population of the [[Pontus (region)|Pontus]] were expelled to [[Greece]]. In 1917, after the [[Russian Revolution]], Lazs became citizents of [[Democratic Republic of Georgia]], and eventually became [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] citizens after the [[Red Army invasion of Georgia]] in 1921. Simultaneously, a [[Treaty of Moscow (1921)|treaty of friendship]] was signed in Moscow between [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]] and the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey]], whereby southern portions of former [[Batum Oblast|Batumi oblast]] - later known as [[Artvin]], was awarded to Turkey, which renounced its claims to Batumi. The autonomous Lazistan sanjak existed until the end of the empire in 1923. the designation of the term of Lazistan was officially banned in 1926, by the [[Kemalism|Kemalists]].Thys-Şenocak, Lucienne. Ottoman Women Builders. Aldershot, England: Ashgate, 2006. Print. Lazistan was divided between [[Rize Province|Rize]] and Artvin provinces. === Modern === Most Laz people today live in Turkey, but the Laz minority group has no official status in Turkey. The number of the Laz speakers is decreasing, and is now limited chiefly to the Rize and Artvin areas. ==== Self-identification ==== Over time the Laz living on either side of the frontier have developed different conceptions of what it means to be Laz. Today, most of those living in Turkey do not consider themselves Turkish, but uphold their Laz identity as a separate one.[https://chai-khana.org/en/the-laz-two-tales-of-one-people Chai-khana.org; ''The Laz: Two Tales of One People'' , Irakli Dzneladze] In contrast, Laz identity in Georgia has largely merged with a Georgian identity, and the meaning of "Laz" is seen as merely a regional category.Minorsky, V. "Laz." Encyclopaedia of Islam, Second Edition. Edited by: P. Bearman , Th. Bianquis , C.E . Bosworth , E. van Donzel and W.P. Heinrichs. Brill, 2010., At the same time, in Turkey, the term Laz is a 'folk' definition for people of different ethnic and linguistic backgrounds originating from the [[Black Sea Region]]. Officially, the Laz people are not recognized as a minority. Thus, many Turks do not even know about their diverse existence and falsely call the inhabitants of the Black Sea coast as the "Lazlar". Within the last decade more and more intellectual Laz people realized that the disappearance of their language would lead to the disappearance of their identity and tried to preserve their inherited culture through political empowerment, linguistic education, and music and poetry. == Population and geographical distribution == {{further|Laz people in Turkey}} The total population of the Laz today is only estimated, with numbers ranging widely. The majority of Laz live in Turkey, where the national census does not record ethnic data on minor populations.{{cite journal|author=Silvia Kutscher|year=2008|title=The language of the Laz in Turkey: Contact-induced language change or gradual loss?|url=http://www.uni-muenster.de/imperia/md/content/allgemeine_sprachwissenschaft/dozenten-unterlagen/kutscher/kutscher_langloss_trkl.pdf|journal=Turkic Languages|volume=12|issue=1|accessdate=31 January 2015|quote=Due to a lack of census information on minorities (aside from a small number of exceptions such as the Greek or Armenian populations), the actual number of Laz living in Turkey can only be estimated}} === Settlements === {| class="wikitable" !Country / region !Official data !Estimate !'''Concentration''' !Article |- |{{flag|Turkey}} |500.000[http://i-cias.com/e.o/turkey_4.htm Encyclopedia of the Orient][http://www.ecoi.net/190288::turkey/328808.327356.9782...mr.570747/laz.htm ecoi.net]http://www.usefoundation.org/view/865 |1.6 million{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/yasam/haber/698621-67-milletten-insanimiz-var|title=67 milletten insanımız var!|author=Bülent Günal|date=20 December 2011|language=tr|accessdate=31 January 2015}} |'''[[Rize]]''': [[Pazar, Rize|Pazar]], [[Ardeşen]], and [[Fındıklı, Rize|Fındıklı]] districts. '''[[Artvin]]''': [[Arhavi]] and [[Hopa]]. minorities in: [[Çamlıhemşin]], [[Borçka]], and [[İkizdere]] districts.
'''[[Anatolia]]''': [[Karamürsel]] in [[İzmit|Kocaeli]], [[Akçakoca]] in [[Düzce Province|Düzce]], [[Sakarya Province|Sakarya]], [[Zonguldak]], [[Bartın Province|Bartın]], [[Istanbul]] and [[Ankara]] |''[[Laz people in Turkey]]'' |- |{{flag|Georgia}} |2,000{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=lzz|title=Laz|work=Ethnologue|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65SUDJt3b|archivedate=2012-02-15}} | |'''[[Tbilisi]]'''
'''[[Adjara]]''': [[Sarpi, Georgia|Sarpi]], [[Kvariati]], [[Gonio]], [[Makho]], [[Batumi]] and [[Kobuleti]]. '''[[Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti]]''': [[Zugdidi]] and [[Anaklia]]. |''[[Laz people in Georgia]]'' |- |{{flag|EU}} |1,000-1,500https://www.ethnologue.com/13/countries/Turk.html
(Germany 1987) | |'''[[Belgium]]''', '''[[France]]''' and '''[[Germany]]'''. |''[[Laz people in Germany]]'' |- |{{flag|Russia}} |160{{cite web|url=http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/croc/Documents/Vol4/pub-04-01.pdf|title=Национальный состав населения|trans-title=2010 Census: Ethnic composition of the population|publisher=[[Russian Federal State Statistics Service]] |accessdate=31 January 2015|language=ru}} |2,000 |'''[[Moscow]]''' |''[[Laz people in Russia]]'' |} === Area === [[File:ჭანეთი აღმოსავლეთ ლაზეთი Lazeti Doğu Lazistan Лазети Лазистан.png|thumb|Map of Eastern Lazona.]] The majority of the Laz today live in an area they call ''Laziǩa, Lazistan, Lazeti'' or ''Lazona'' name of the cultural region traditionally inhabited by the Laz people in modern northeast Turkey and southwest Georgia. Geographically, Lazistan consists of a series of narrow, rugged valleys extending northward from the crest of the [[Pontic Mountains|Pontic Alps]] ({{lang-tr|Anadolu Dağları}}), which separate it from the [[Çoruh River|Çoruh]] Valley, and stretches east-west along the southern shore of the [[Black Sea]]. Lazistan is a virtually a forbidden term in Turkey.{{efn-ua|"Article 8 of the Anti-Terror Law (Law No. 3713 amended by Law No. 4126) reads, “No one may engage in written and oral propaganda aimed at disrupting the indivisible integrity of the State of the Turkish Republic, country, and nation. [… ] Those who engage in such deeds will be sentenced to from one to three years in prison and given a heavy fine… ”. This article means that those who orally or in print make use of words such as Lazistan or Kurdistan risk prosecution."}} the name was considered to be an 'unpatriotic' invention of ancien regime. Laz ancestral lands are not well-defined and there is no official geographic definition for the boundaries of Lazistan. However, the following provinces are usually included: * [[Adjara]] region in Georgia * [[Artvin Province|Artvin]] province in Turkey * [[Rize Province|Rize]] province in Turkey * [[Trabzon Province|Trabzon]] province in Turkey === Economy === Historically, Lazistan was known for producing [[hazelnut]]s.{{cite book|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/11768/view/1/52/|title=Armenia and Kurdistan|last=Prothero|first=W.G.|publisher=H.M. Stationery Office|year=1920|location=London|page=52}} Lazistan also produced [[zinc]], producing over 1,700 tons in 1901.{{cite book|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/11768/view/1/73/|title=Armenia and Kurdistan|last=Prothero|first=W.G.|publisher=H.M. Stationery Office|year=1920|location=London|page=73}} The traditional Laz economy was based on agriculture—carried out with some difficulty in the steep mountain regions and also on the breeding of sheep, goats, and cattle. Orchards were tended and bees were kept, and the food supply was augmented by hunting. The Laz are good sailors and also practise agriculture rice, maize, tobacco and fruit-trees. The only industries were smelting, celebrated since ancient times, and the cutting of timber used for shipbuilding. ==Culture== Over the past 20 years, there has been an upsurge of cultural activities aiming at revitalizing the Laz language, education and tradition. [[Kâzım Koyuncu]], who in 1998 became the first Laz musician to gain mainstream success, contributed significantly to the identity of the Laz people, especially among their youth.{{cite web|url=http://www.bianet.org/bianet/siyaset/161339-90-lar-laz-kultur-ve-kimlik-hareketinin-dogusu|title=90’lar: Laz Kültür ve Kimlik Hareketinin Doğuşu|author=Ismail Güney Yılmaz|date=7 January 2015|publisher=Lazebura|language=tr|trans-title=1990s: The Birth of the Laz Culture and Identity Movement|accessdate=31 January 2015}} The Laz Cultural Institute was founded in 1993 and the Laz Culture Association in 2008, and a Laz cultural festival was established in [[Gemlik]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/croc/Documents/Vol4/pub-04-01.pdf|title=Национальный состав населения|trans-title=2010 Census: Ethnic composition of the population|publisher=[[Russian Federal State Statistics Service]] |accessdate=31 January 2015|language=ru}}{{cite web|url=http://lazca.org/yazarlar/kamil-aksoylu-toroci/188-laz-kulturu-hareket-93-surecnden-laz-ensttusune.html |title=Laz Kültürü Hareketi̇ 93 Süreci̇nden Laz Ensti̇tüsüne |publisher=Lazca.org|author=Kâmil Aksoylu |date=3 July 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2015 |language=tr}} The Laz community successfully lobbied Turkey's Education Ministry to offer Laz-language instruction in schools around the Black Sea region. In 2013, the Education Ministry added Laz as a four-year elective course for secondary students, beginning in the fifth grade.{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/lazuri-classes-to-begin-in-secondary-schools-in-turkey.aspx?pageID=238&nid=54429 |title=Lazuri classes to begin in secondary schools in Turkey |agency=Anadolou |date=14 September 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2015}} === Language === {{further|Laz language}}[[File:Kartvelian_languages.svg|thumb|250x250px|Distribution of the [[Kartvelian languages]].|right]]Lazuri is a complex and morphologically rich tongue belonging to the South Caucasian language family whose other members are Mingrelian, Svanetian, and Georgian. The Laz language does not have a written history, thus Turkish and Georgian serve as the main literary languages for the Laz people. Their folk literature has been transmitted orally and has not been systematically recorded. The first attempts at establishing a distinct Laz cultural identity and creating a literary language based on the [[Arabic alphabet]] was made by Faik Efendisi in the 1870s, but he was soon imprisoned by the Ottoman authorities, while most of his works were destroyed. During a relative cultural autonomy granted to the minorities in the 1930s, the written Laz literature—based on the Laz script—emerged in [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet Georgia]], strongly dominated by Soviet ideology. The poet Mustafa Baniṣi spearheaded this short-lived movement, but an official standard form of the tongue was never established.{{cite book|url=http://feb-web.ru/feb/litenc/encyclop/le6/le6-0292.htm|title=Лазская литература|author=Iksander Tsitashi|work=Литературная энциклопедия (Encyclopedia of Literature)|year=1939|location=Moscow|language=ru|trans-title=Laz literature}} Since then, several attempts have been made to render the pieces of native literature in the Turkish and Georgian alphabets. A few native poets in Turkey such as Raşid Hilmi and Pehlivanoğlu have appeared later in the 20th century. === Religion === One of the chief tribes of ancient kingdom of [[Colchis]], the Laz were converted to [[Christianity]] while living under the [[Byzantine Empire]] and the [[Kingdom of Georgia]]. [[Trabzon|Trebizond]], which was the only diocese established far in the past, [[Giresun|Cerasous]] and [[Rize|Rizaion]] in [[Lazia (Pontus)|Lazia]], both formed as upgraded bishoprics. All three dioceses survived the Ottoman conquest (1461) and generally operated until the 17th century, when the dioceses of Cerasous and Rizaion were abolished. The diocese of Rizaion and the bishopric of [[Of, Turkey|Of]] were abolished at the time due to the [[Islamization|Islamisation]] of the Lazs. Most of them subsequently converted to [[Sunni Islam]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPZtAAAAMAAJ&q=laz+colchian&dq=laz+colchian&lr=&cd=17|title=Ethnoarchaeology of Anatolia: rural socio-economy in the Bronze and Iron Ages|work=Jak Yakar|publisher=Google Books|accessdate=26 May 2014|quote=Formerly Christians, they converted to Sunni Islam a little over four centuries ago.}}[[Özhan Öztürk]]. [http://www.yeniansiklopedi.com/pontus-anticag’dan-gunumuze-karadeniz’in-etnik%20-ve-siyasi-tarihi/ Pontus]. Genesis Yayınları. İstanbul, 2009. s. 737-38, 778 There are also a few Christian Laz in the [[Adjaria]] region of Georgia who have converted to Christianity.Roger Rosen, Jeffrey Jay Foxx (September 1991) ''The Georgian Republic'', Passport Books, Lincolnwood, IL {{ISBN|978-0-84429-677-7}} {{double image|center|Sarpi Village, Georgia.jpg|250|Sarpi_Church.jpg|222|Mosque and Orthodox church in Sarpi, border village on the coast of the Black Sea, on the border between Turkey and Georgia.}} === Mythology === [[File:Château de Versailles, salon de Diane, Jason et les Argonautes débarquant en Colchide, Charles de La Fosse.jpg|thumb|[[Jason]] and the [[Argonauts]] arriving at Colchis. [[Argonautica]] tells the myth of their voyage to retrieve the [[Golden Fleece]]. This painting is located in the [[Palace of Versailles]].|250x250px]] Famous for its saga and myths and bounded by the Black Sea and the Caucasian Mountains, the ancient region of Colchis spreads out from West Georgia to Northeast Turkey. The famous tale in Greek mythology of the [[Golden Fleece]] in which Jason and the [[Argonauts]] stole the Golden Fleece from King [[Aeëtes|Aeetes]], with the help of his daughter [[Medea]], has brought Colchis into the history books. === Festival === [[Kolkhoba]] is an ancient Laz festival. It is held at the end of August or at the beginning of September in [[Sarpi, Georgia|Sarpi village]], [[Khelvachauri Municipality|Khelvachauri District]]. Festival has revived the former lifestyle of Lazeti residents and moments of human relations typical to the times of [[ancient Greece]] and [[Colchis]] related to the [[Argonauts]] journey to Colchis. During the celebration of Kolkhoba theater performances are followed by a variety of activities and it is considered one of the main public festivals. === Music === The national instruments include [[Tulum (bagpipe)|guda]] (bagpipe), [[kemenche]] (spike fiddle), [[zurna]] (oboe), and [[doli (musical instrument)|doli]] (drum). In the 1990s and 2000s, the [[folk-rock]] musician [[Kâzım Koyuncu]] attained to significant popularity in Turkey and toured Georgia. Koyuncu, who died of cancer in 2005, was also an activist for the Laz people and has become a cultural hero.{{Cite book| publisher = Berghahn Books| isbn = 978-0-85745-769-1| last1 = Hake| first1 = Sabine| last2 = Mennel| first2 = Barbara| title = Turkish German Cinema in the New Millennium: Sites, Sounds, and Screens| date = 2012-10-01 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=itVXmVfBz08C&pg=PA204}} === Dance === [[File:Verbreitungskarte der türkischen Volkstänze.png|thumb|250x250px|Extension and distribution of [[folk dance]]s in [[Turkey]].]] The Laz are noted for their folk dances, called the [[Horon (dance)|Horon]] dance of the Black Sea, originally of pagan worship which was to become a sacred ritual dance. There are many different types of this dance in different regions. Horon is related to those performed by the [[Adjarians|Ajarians]] known as [[Khorumi]]. These may be solemn and precise, performed by lines of men, with carefully executed footwork, or extremely vigorous with the men dancing erect with hands linked, making short rapid movements with their feet, punctuated by dropping to a crouch. The women's dances are graceful but more swift in movement than those encountered in Georgia. In Greece such dances are still associated with the [[Pontic Greeks]] who emigrated from this region after 1922. === Traditional clothing === [[File:Le courageux Pir-aga Moustafa-reize avec sa compagnie..jpg|thumb|244x244px|Postcard of Laz soldiers dressed in national clothes (Trabzon, Turkey).]] The traditional Laz men's costume consists of a peculiar bandanalike kerchief covering the entire head above the eyes, knotted on the side and hanging down to the shoulder and the upper back; a snug-fitting jacket of coarse brown homespun with loose sleeves; and baggy dark brown woolen trousers tucked into slim, knee-high leather boots. The women's costume was similar to the wide-skirted princess gown found throughout Georgia but worn with a similar kerchief to that of the men and with a rich scarf tied around the hips. Laz men crafted excellent homemade rifles and even while at the plow were usually seen bristling with arms: rifle, pistol, powder horn, cartridge belts across the chest, a dagger at the hip, and a coil of rope for trussing captives. === Cuisine === Laz cuisine specialities include: * ''[[Kuymak|Mıhlama]] ''– a filling corn meal, butter, and cheese fondue; * ''[[Anchovy|Hamsi pilavı]] ''– spiced rice enclosed in fried Black Sea anchovies; * ''[[Kuru fasulye]] – ''white beans in a tomato sauce; * ''[[Börek|Laz böreği]] ''– a custard filled ''baklava ''like dessert; * ''[[Pita|Karadeniz pidesi]] ''– an elongated and closed form of the popular pide dish. === Discrimination === [[File:Renamed place names in Turkey.png|thumb|302x302px|Percentage of geographical name changes in Turkey from 1916 onwards]] [[Mustafa Kemal Ataturk]], the leader of the early decades of the Republic, aimed to create a nation state ({{lang-tr|Ulus}}) from the Turkish remnants of the Ottoman Empire. During the first three decades of the Republic, efforts to Turkify geographical names were a recurring theme. Imported maps containing references to historical regions such as Armenia, Kurdistan, or Lazistan (the official name of the province of [[Rize]] until 1921) were prohibited (as was the case with ''Der Grosse Weltatlas'', a map published in [[Leipzig]]). Cultural assimilation into the Turkish culture has been high, and Laz identity was oppressed during the days of Ottoman and Soviet Rule. One of the pivotal moments was in 1992, when the book ''Laz History'' (''Lazların tarihi'') was published. The authors had failed to have it published in 1964. == Notable Lazs == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} * [[Mircan Kaia]], Turkish musician and songwriter. * [[:ka:იოანე ლაზი|Ioane Lazi]], a Georgian [[theologian]] and [[philosopher]], со-author of the works of the [[Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite]]. * [[Ioane Petritsi]], a [[Georgians|Georgian]] [[Neoplatonist]] philosopher of the 11th-12th century, active in the [[Byzantine Empire]] and [[Kingdom of Georgia]], best known for his translations of [[Proclus]], along with an extensive commentary. * [[Laz Ahmed Pasha]], an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] statesman. He was as the [[Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire]] briefly between 1811-1812. * [[:tr:İskender Chitaşi|İskender Chitaşi]], a Laz Linguist, writer and activist. * [[Sezen Aksu]], a [[Turkish people|Turkish]] [[Turkish pop music|pop music]] singer, songwriter and producer who has sold over 40 million albums worldwide. {{refimprove|date=November 2008}} The '''Longuda''' are a West African ethnic group living in Adamawa and Gombe States in northeastern [[Nigeria]]. They are the only known matriarchal tribe in Nigeria. The Longuda consider [[matrilineal]] descent in many aspects of their [[social organisation]] more important than the [[patrilineal]] descent. [[Clan]] membership may even be counted on the mother line. This custom is not found with their other neighbors or in other tribes of [[Nigeria]]. The [[Longuda language]] is a branch of [[Adamawa languages|Adamawa]]. == History and geography == The Longuda rulers default to the [[Kanuri people|Kanuri]] style. The seat of the traditional ruler is in [[Guyuk, Nigeria|Guyuk]], [[Adamawa State]]. According to oral tradition, the Longuda parted from the [[Kanuri people|Kanuri]] in [[Borno State]]. == Cuisine == [[File:Guineacorn.jpg|thumb|Guinea Corn (''[[Sorghum bicolor]]'')]] Traditionally, the [[staple crop]] of the Longuda is Guinea Corn (''[[Sorghum bicolor]]''). This used to be grounded on stone hand mill and cooked into a thick paste, ''"tuwo"'', then eaten with vegetable soup. Today, however, [[rice]], [[maize]], and [[millet]] form part of the staple of the Longuda. Guinea Corn still remains the dominant crop grown by the Longuda. == Marriage == The Longuda are primarily [[polygamous]]. The different dialects of the Longuda people perform [[marriage]] rites differently. Traditionally, a young man courting a woman invited his friends on the night he wished to take her as his bride, without her prior knowledge. The man and his friends would abduct the woman to his cottage, often a forceful act. Once the woman spent a night in his cottage, his family and hers considered them married. The [[bride price]] was usually paid afterwards. This [[Bride kidnapping|abduction]], which usually took place in the night, was not without resistance. The other young men in the woman's neighborhood would attempt to come to her rescue, and a free-for-all fight would ensue. The intending groom and his company usually had to win the duel in order to take the bride-to-be. However, in recent times, the influence of [[Christianity]] and [[cultural assimilation]] of neighboring societies have altered this practice. A watered-down version of this is still widely used. In this case, a man asks a woman for her consent, the woman agrees, and on an arranged night, the groom's friends and bride's friends secretly picks her and her clothing up from her parents' house, goes over to spend the night in the groom's uncle's house, leaving behind a token at the position where they used to sit during courtship and that seals the union. Taking her clothes along with her is her indication to everyone that she has agreed to marry the man. == Publications == [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=lnu Newman, Bonnie. 1976. "Deep and surface structure of the Longuda clause."]
[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=lnu Newman, Bonnie. 1978. "The Longuda verb."]
[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=lnu Newman, John F. 1978. "Participant orientation in Longuda folk tales."]
[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=lnu Newman, John F. and Bonnie Newman. 1974. "Longuda."]
[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=lnu Newman, John F. and Bonnie Newman. 1977. Longuda dialect survey.]
